Extending upon ideas established in 2001's cult classic Pimps Don't Pay Taxes, J-Zone's new Peter Pan Syndrome delivers layered, painstakingly battered into shape hip-hop compositions.

title: Pull My Hair Back
label: Hyperdub
description: Hamilton, Ontario vocalist Jessy Lanza works with Jeremy Greenspan of Junior Boys on a collection of glacial electro-R&B. Pull My Hair Back rings with a level of confidence surprising for a first record.

title: The 1975
label: Polydor
description: The 1975 emerged in 2011 as the third-wave emo band the Slowdown, then quickly disappeared. A couple years later, the rebooted Manchester group's spit-polished self-titled full-length aims for the gleaming synth rock of Phoenix and M83.

title: Nobody Knows
label: XL
description: On Willis Earl Beal's second album, Nobody Knows, the music is more diverse and expansive than it was on his 2012 debut, Acousmatic Sorcery. Sounds and styles he only had the tools to hint at before are rendered professionally and in high definition, and his voice is given the sonic space it probably deserves.

title: Tales of Us
label: Mute
description: On their sixth album, Goldfrapp come as close as they ever have to returning to the sound of 2000's Felt Mountain, the album that originally made them famous. Touching on that record’s folkier side and running with it, Tales of Us is every bit as fragile as the romantic themes it obsesses over.

title: Nobody Realizes This Is Nowhere
label: Slumberland
description: San Fran scuzz-punkers Terry Malts return with their second album, Nobody Realizes This Is Nowhere. The playing is punchy and the songs are pretty much ripped right out of your pop-punk textbook, frantically careening from one power-chord to the next.

title: Surgical Steel
label: Nuclear Blast
description: Liverpool death metal pioneers Carcass' immaculately produced, linguistically rich comeback album might be calculated, but it doesn't feel forced: Surgical Steel is a document of middle-aged lifers trading ponderous maturity for the visceral thrills they relished in their prime.

title: Infinity Caller
label: Western Vinyl
description: Brooklyn indie rockers Grooms have been playing together since they went by the name Muggabears, and now their assured interplay is a joy in itself. Their guitars tangle and pull apart like kite strings, and the drums hit with a gentle splash on their new Infinity Caller.

title: AM
label: Domino
description: Over the last eight years, the Arctic Monkeys have gone from spastic punk, to doomed stoner rock, to sparkling guitar pop, to their fifth album's skinny-jeaned funk. On AM, the quartet, now based in Los Angeles, offer a paranoid, haunted collection that goes beyond the sweaty clubs and furtive flirts into the hotel rooms, after parties, and bad decisions that can follow.

title: Olive Juice
label: Elestial Sound
description: Orlando-born singer and synth manipulator Emily Reo's first album for Elestial Sounds, the Gainesville record label/collective behind Hundred Waters, finds her sharpening her older lo-fi material and sweeping away the tape-deck dust to reveal a palette of bright colors.

title: On Oni Pond
label: Anti-
description: Like every album from experimental Philly rock band Man Man, their new On Oni Pond finds the wolfish crew to be more traditionally tuneful and less grating than the last time out.

title: Coming Apart
label: Matador
description: Body/Head is the minimalist duo of ex-Sonic Youth bassist Kim Gordon and experimental guitarist Bill Nace. On their intoxicating first full length, where both play guitar and Gordon sings, the duo treat a limited palette as a challenge, like the straitjacket a magician dons to prove he can break free.

title: The Electric Lady
label: Bad Boy
description: Janelle Monáe's second album is looser and more physical than her 2010 debut ArchAndroid. Together with her tight-knit Wondaland collaborators (and with guest spots from Prince, Erykah Badu, Miguel, and Solange), she supervises and synthesizes a parade of golden era touchstones into a showstopping display of force and talent.

title: Troubadour
label: Stones Throw
description: The Connecticut trio the Stepkids make vintage-sounding soul that occasionally slides over into full-on funk. Their new album, Troubadour, is a loose concept album that showcases a blissfully uncluttered sound.

title: Smilewound
label: Morr
description: Blending classical and rock instrumentation with glitchy beats, ambient electronics, and stagy vocals, the Icelandic band Múm's music taps into a spirit of childlike wonder. The best songs on Smilewound, including a bonus track featuring Kylie Minogue, hint at svelte, engaging electro-pop.

title: Age Against the Machine
label: Elektra
description: Getting the band back together seems counterintuitive to Cee-Lo’s career trajectory, but it makes sense for the rest of the members of Atlanta rap veterans Goodie Mob. The reunited foursome’s just-released Age Against the Machine, while bright in spots, seems to filter the breakout success of Cee-Lo back through the rest of the group.

title: Stitches
label: Dead Oceans
description: The music of experimental rock outfit Califone has always been rooted in the tension between technology and humanity. On the new Stiches, leader Tim Rutili leans a little more heavily on the human element.

title: Kiss Land
label: Republic
description: Following three mixtapes released in quick succession that contained some of the most influential and gripping R&B of the new decade, Abel Tesfaye's bleak and atmospheric project makes its major label debut.

title: Summer Through My Mind
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: At this point, the Glaswegian singer, guitarist, improviser, and experimentalist Richard Youngs can do just about anything and still sound like himself. On Summer Through My Mind, he offers a collection of slightly unhinged but almost relentlessly tuneful Americana songs.

title: Pain Is Beauty
label: Sargent House
description: On her latest album, the goth-folk artist with an ear for black metal adds layers of electronics and a new sense of grandeur to the mix. The result is her best and most emotionally direct work yet.

title: Sundowning
label: Notes and Bolts
description: On their second album, Chicago’s Pink Frost, formerly Apteka, dial down the sludge and guitar drone, writing songs you can almost imagine hearing on rock radio. There’s sonic common ground between Sundowning and early Smashing Pumpkins, most of it good assuming you don’t use “alt rock” as a pejorative.

title: Hands on the Controls
label: Castle Face
description: The reissue of the joyfully spastic debut album by the Coachwhips, John Dwyer's band prior to Thee Oh Sees, offers the group's 2002 collection on vinyl for the first time, along with six bonus tracks. Viewed in its original context, Hands on the Controls can be seen as an emergency retoxification of garage rock in the wake of the Strokes and the White Stripes.

title: Law and Order
label: Woodsist
description: Law & Order-- the solo debut from Foxygen's Jonathan Rado-- suggests Rado is fully prepared to make Foxygen records on his own. The collection sketches out a homemade grab-bag of jams and rough-cut gems devoted to monolithic 60s rock sounds.

title: Run Fast
label: Dischord
description: After years of battling long-progressed Lyme disease, Kathleen Hannah resurrected her 1997 solo project Julie Ruin as a full band in 2010. To call their proper debut Run Fast “invigorated” would be missing the hyperkinetic point.

title: The Worse Things Get, the Harder I Fight...
label: Anti-
description: Neko Case’s remarkable new album, The Worse Things Get, the Harder I Fight, the Harder I Fight, the More I Love You is an exorcism of a dark period of her life, and her most plainly autobiographical album to date. It also could be the most potent record of her career.

title: Sky Swallower
label: Century Media
description: Vattnet Viskar's awe-inspiring, violently gorgeous first full-length, Sky Swallower, finds the New Hampshire metal band raging and mourning across massive sonic spaces. In a field where every choice of drum beat is loaded with specific, coded information, they pluck useful material from wherever they find it.

title: Surrounded
label: Merge
description: For 20 years, Richard Buckner has elusively drifted through alt-country, electric folk, acoustic rock. Recently, he's explored more serene textures, but he regains some of his former rawness on new discography highlight Surrounded, an LP filled with gorgeously charged songs.

title: Idle No More
label: Merge
description: In the six years that have passed since King Khan and his band the Shrines last released a new album, Arish Khan’s sassy self-deprecation has turned to sobering introspection, and with good reason. Idle No More, his first proper record with a U.S. label, evinces a new sense of purpose.

title: Repave
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Volcano Choir is Bon Iver's Justin Vernon with Wisconsin experimental post-rock outfits Collections of Colonies of Bees and All Tiny Creatures. On their second LP Repave, the sextet have created a grandiose record featuring arena-rock ambitions and ostentatious beauty.

title: Forever
label: Captured Tracks
description: After a long tour, Swedish punks Holograms returned home poor and hopeless. Going for broke, their sophomore LP Forever transform their pitch-black palate of sounds into something remarkably bright and emotionally charged.

title: John Wizards
label: Planet Mu
description: John Wizards is the project of 25-year-old Cape Town, South Africa resident John Withers. His debut album mixes styles that are, as goes the great promise of cultural consumption in the internet age, pan-global. It ranges from the peppy end of Ghanaian highlife to the crisp optimism of Withers' native mbaqanga, from 80s disco to swing-heavy instrumental hip-hop.

title: The Silver Gymnasium
label: ATO
description: Okkervil River's first release for the ATO label is a concept album about innocence and youth, showing a kid's first glimpses into the adult world. It's set in the 1980s and comes with a map of Will Sheff’s hometown of Meriden, New Hampshire, showing where each song takes place.

title: Hesitation Marks
label: Columbia
description: For the first Nine Inch Nails release since 2009, Trent Reznor has resorted to the most radical release strategy an independent-minded artist can employ in 2013: he’s re-signed to a major label. But unlike the themes of depression, madness, and addiction that defined his most enduring works, the skeletal Hesitation Marks chronicles a more existential crisis.

title: All Uproarious Darkness
label: Profound Lore
description: Vasaeleth's 2010 debut album Crypt-Born and Tethered to Ruin was a sleeper hit with the black/death elite. Three years later, instead of an epic full-length, we’ve been blindsided with an EP. In a subgenre often characterized by excess, the Georgia/Colorado duo have delivered a short, savage lethal strike.

title: Golden Suits
label: Yep Roc
description: Golden Suits is the new folk-pop project from Department of Eagles' Fred Nicolaus. In the year leading up to this sumptuous self-titled debut, he went broke, saw the end of a longstanding relationship, lost an apartment to a rat infestation, and dropped 40 pounds.

title: False Memories
label: L.I.E.S.
description: Brooklyn dance label Long Island Electrical Systems's inaugural full-length artist release comes from Marcos Cabral. The producer surfaced in 2008 as one half of Brooklyn duo Runaway and his 2011 solo L.I.E.S.-imprinted 24 Hour Flight EP turned heads to Cabral and the label that released it.

title: Slave Vows
label: Agitated
description: Los Angeles sleaze merchants Icarus Line continue on their road to redemption with their new Slave Vows, their best record since Penance Soiree. On Slave Vows,songs start out comely, lurching and depraved, only to explode into id-startled fits of furious chaos and noise-- nothing feels forced or wasted.

title: Bootleg Series, Vol. 10: Another Self Portrait (1969-1971)
label: Columbia
description: The latest entry in Bob Dylan’s frequently brilliant Bootleg Series focuses on previously unreleased music recorded around the time of the savagely reviewed 1970 double album Self Portrait. Included among the alternate takes, demos, stripped-down mixes, and live cuts are songs that wound up on New Morning and Nashville Skyline.

label: Drag City
description: Venom P. Stinger-- featuring Mick Turner and Jim White (later of the Dirty Three)-- were an Australian quartet that started songs with a simple beat and a few chords, but revved into noisier, wilder territory. The compilation 1986-1991 collects their first four releases, spotlighting a group for whom energy and insanity were higher priorities than melody.

title: Generic Treasure
label: Don Giovanni
description: Joe Steinhardt is the co-founder of New Jersey's Don Giovanni Records, home to Waxahatchee, Screaming Females, California X, and others. His debut LP as Modern Hut, produced by Screaming Females' Marissa Paternoster, is a sparse, straightforward anti-folk record.

title: Mon Pays
label: Six Degrees
description: The translated title of Malian vocalist/guitarist Vieux Farka Touré’s newest album Mon Pays is My Country. The compulsively listenenable collection feels like his conscious effort to wrap his arms around Mali and its many sounds, and to show how they can come together to make something coherent.

title: Higher!
label: Epic / Legacy
description: The 4xCD Higher! expands on Sly & the Family Stone's history and big-picture role in the development of pop and soul, acting as that rare box set that works as both an introduction for the unaware and a deep excursion into further context for dedicated fans. It's a perfectly balanced mix of stuff casual fans know and stuff even obsessives haven't heard.

title: 6 Feet Beneath the Moon
label: XL
description: Armed with a blood-freezing voice, the 19-year-old Londoner Archy Marshall recorded his haunting early songs on a malfunctioning laptop, first as Zoo Kid then as King Krule. His Rodaidh McDonald-produced debut for True Panther/XL sounds roomier and warmer, but it's the same chipped-brick urban landscape Marshall prowled through on his previous work.

title: Eccentric Soul: The Forte Label
label: Numero Group
description: The Forte Label-- the latest archival anthology in Numero Group’s consistently superb Eccentric Soul series-- compiles the speedy, saucy funk recordings of Kansas City label Forte. The collection prominently features underappreciated performances from James Brown collaborator Marva Whitney.

title: Feast of Love
label: Run for Cover
description: On their debut LP, the co-ed Ann Arbor quartet Pity Sex offer post-coital pop-punk that's melodic and punchy enough to be attractive, but rumpled and lethargic enough to let you know they're not trying too hard.

title: No Better Time Than Now
label: Ghostly
description: On projects like Lineage and Full Circle, the Michigan producer Zach Saginaw demonstrated the ability to gravitate from the gentle pastoral sound associated with early Four Tet to more stripped-down, driving sounds. His new No Better Time Than Now is, at times, both puzzling and beautiful.

title: Tough Love
label: Fool's Gold
description: Justin “Party Supplies” Nealis produced Action Bronson’s Blue Chips mixtape, and he's a hyperactive MPC jockey who builds beats from scratch in front of a live audience. Neither experience is an indicator of what to expect from his first proper album Tough Love, a collection that finds him in the role of the slightly sensitive electropop singer-songwriter.

title: The Third Eye Centre
label: Matador
description: Belle and Sebastian's The Third Eye Centre compilation cobbles together a cherry-picked sampling of post-2003 rarities in randomized order. It’s an odd approach for a band that’s put so much effort into proper album presentation, but one that’s reflective of the more freewheeling nature of their post-2000 records.

title: Era
label: Kranky
description: Chicago’s Disappears return with a more eclectic album. Here they grab the more anemic sounds of Clinic and Liars, while keeping the forward momentum of their most obvious influences, Spacemen 3 and rough-edged Velvet Underground.

title: Flaamingos
label: Felte
description: The LA duo Flaamingos' self-titled debut is steely, stone-faced, black-coffee-and-cigarette music, a sound that easily recalls Depeche Mode or Echo and the Bunnymen. Though the album relies on programmed drums and downcast synths, Flaamingos succeeds when little bursts of neon jut out through the darkness.

title: Carrier
label: Polyvinyl
description: San Francisco duo Dodos' fifth album is their most subdued and solemn. The autumnal Carrier was inspired by the passing of guitarist Christopher Reimer, who joined Dodos for a brief period between his departure from Women and his death at the age of 26 in 2012.

title: Engravings
label: Tri Angle
description: On Forest Swords’ 2010 EP Dagger Paths, the web of dub, psych, dance, and drone spun by UK producer Matthew Barnes felt instantly singular. Engravings is the perfect sequel, cementing his knack for creating complex effects with elementary methods. Every song here is boldly sensual, and each note has a distinct emotional hue.

title: Quiet Moments
label: Handmade Birds
description: For over two decades, Arizona's Lycia have been pioneers of “darkwave,” a reverb-drenched, gothic take on dreampop. Quiet Moments, their first release for Handmade Birds, is a somber, but beautiful collection that offers an intriguing meditation on mystery and loss.

title: Feels Weird
label: Father/Daughter
description: Originally known as Girlfriends, Boston garage pop trio Bent Shapes draw on proto- and post-punk influences like the Feelies and Jonathan Richman. Their proper debut gathers the frenetic declarations, judgments, and uncertainties that have become part of the band's character.

title: Colored Sands
label: Season of Mist
description: Gorguts' first record since 2001 features founding member Luc Lemay surrounded by members of Krallice, Dysrhythmia, and Origin. Colored Sands, an album of breathtaking detail and scope, contains some of the thorniest, most aggressive death metal ever issued under the classic Quebec band's name, as well as moments of stunning textural beauty.

title: Warm Blanket
label: Paw Tracks
description: On Warm Blanket, the singer-songwriter revisits his familiar mundane themes with fuller orchestrations, showing a debt to and admiration of Brian Wilson is more prominent than ever. But he runs into some long-standing problems when it comes to actually saying something in his songs.

title: Right Thoughts, Right Words, Right Action
label: Domino
description: After a four year hiatus, Franz Ferdinand release their fourth album, Right Thoughts, Right Words, Right Action, a collection produced by the band with Bjorn Yttling and Todd Terje. It finds them reestablishing themselves as a workmanlike, crowd-pleasing dance-rock group by going heavy on the midtempo disco thump.

title: Necrocracy
label: Relapse
description: The California death metal band Exhumed’s 2011 comeback album, All Guts, No Glory made it clear the group still had plenty of curdled piss and vinegar left. With Necrocracy, they've traded the sloppy savagery for a more refined, melodic kind of audio violence.

title: Love Now
label: Fat Possum
description: A sweet boy-girl indie-pop band is inevitably going to invoke comparisons to She & Him. But Love Now, the Delaware duo's first record for Fat Possum, draws more from Amber Coffman and Dave Longstreth's discordant chemistry, or even the dreamy dub of Peaking Lights.

title: Perpetual Surrender
label: Jagjaguwar
description: Toronto artists Joseph Shabason (the sax player from Destroyer's Kaputt) and Kieran Adams team with vocalist Carmen Elle to craft a promising debut filled with woozy electro-pop. It's a vibe-heavy record that also offers some surprisingly strong hooks.

title: Crimes of Passion
label: Zoo Music
description: San Diego noise pop outfit Crocodiles are so studious in retracing the moves of their 80s post-punk forbears that their most interesting moments come when they start drawing outside the lines. Their new Crimes of Passion is brasher, nervier, and a lot more fun than previous efforts.

title: Nepenthe
label: Dead Oceans
description: Over the course of her career, Juliana Barwick has perfected a very particular form of ethereal vocal ambience. For her new album, she recorded in Iceland with Sigur Rós collaborator Alex Somers, members of múm, and the string quartet Amiina, resulting in her most emotionally complex work yet.

title: Mourning Trance
label: Arts & Crafts
description: Toronto indie rock quintet Still Life Still follow their occasionally immature 2009 Kevin Drew co-produced debut with Mourning Trance, a weightier collection impacted by the deaths of one member's parents and a close friend of the group.

title: Warp and Weft
label: Bella Union
description: Singer/songwriter Laura Veirs' latest Warp and Weft conjures a low, angular desert with percussion like rattlesnakes, guitars like scorpion stings, and pedal steels and string bends like reeling stars, all reverberating into shrouded gray distances.

title: Jet Black Raider EP
label: Moshi Moshi
description: Scottish composer Anna Meredith adds real clarinets, glockenspiels, drums, cello, and even singing to the virtual instruments on her new EP, but otherwise picks up in the same retro-flavored, high-spirited, questing mood of last year's Black Prince Fury.

title: Trap Lord
label: Polo Grounds / RCA
description: Darold Ferguson Jr.-- best known as A$AP Ferg, a member of A$AP Rocky’s A$AP Mob crew-- brings a tantalizing skillset to the table, a startling versatility and an electricity that not even his more famous friend can boast. Those skills are evident on Trap Lord, a release that began life as a mixtape and has been transformed into his major label debut.

title: Roachy Balboa Round 3
label: self-released
description: Bay area rapper Roach Gigz is a young rapper with a quick mind, an eye for the small things, and an off-the-cuff flow with a heavy debt to Lil Wayne. But despite his bullish optimism on his new R**oachy Balboa 3, it still doesn't feel like the shot that will convert regional buzz to national buzz.

title: So You Are... So You'll Be
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The New York psych-rock band moves away from pummeling riffage in favor of spacey explorations, with bits of shoegaze and kosmische drfit in the mix. It's a cleaner, more spacious approach, one not without its charms.

title: Whenever, If Ever
artist: The World Is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die
label: Top Shelf
description: The World is a Beautiful Place & I Am No Longer Afraid to Die have become a cause célèbre as emo reemerges as a viable genre of independent rock rather than a pejorative adjective. The Connecticut collective's ambitious debut LP is powered by an almost frightening will to live.

title: Deep Trip
label: Sacred Bones
description: Fronted by onetime Jay Reatard collaborator Ryan Rousseau, the Arizona collective Destruction Unit's chaotic sophomore album Deep Trip is spacey and punky, and it refuses to acknowledge that there’s anything remotely untoward about that particular alchemy of elements.

title: Sleeper
label: Drag City
description: Sleeper's title can be seen as a comment on Ty Segall's own prolificacy but it also has a deeper resonance. It's a largely acoustic album that meditates on death and loss, a record that owes a debt to Tyrannosaurus Rex-era Marc Bolan or early Bert Jansch.

title: The Wild Hunt
label: Century Media
description: Imagining Watain as one of the most popular heavy metal bands in the world is easy: During the last decade, the Swedish group have stretched and sculpted primitive black metal into an invigorated update on the sound. Their first album in three years finds them attempting to push further past their expected border, complete with a nine minute lighters-up ballad.

title: No Regerts
label: Help Yourself
description: The women in the Seattle pop punk group Chastity Belt met and formed in college, and their debut is sly and charming about college, and fresh-out-of-college concerns. No Regerts breathes some of the same untroubled air as the first Vampire Weekend album.

title: History of Man
label: Bromance
description: After becoming the Weeknd’s personal sound guru, Carlo "Illangelo" Montagnese was perfectly poised to ascend from behind the board to legitimate pop stardom. Instead, Montagnese has taken the more unorthodox path of releasing an album of challenging electronic music that’s also an adaptation of Milton’s Paradise Lost.

title: An Object
label: Sub Pop
description: No Age's strikingly spare third album proves that all the reverb, feedback, and velocity of their past work were hardly afterthoughts or subversive tactics to disguise pop songs. For the most part, An Object consists of potential rock songs denied everything they need to actually rock*.*

title: Between Two Worlds
label: Three Lobed
description: With Between Two Worlds, guitarist Danny Paul Grody (Tarentel, the Drift), offers a singular acoustic guitar album that folds piano chords, synth drones, tape manipulation, and wordless vocals into the mix. It might be the best album of his career.

title: Permanent Signal
label: Secretly Canadian
description: When Porcelain Raft’s first singles started circulating in 2010, Mauro Remiddi distinguished himself with electronic pop that stood out for their craft as opposed to being mere conveyances of vibe. His new LP Permanent Signal presents a less resonant collection of similar ideas.

title: Doris
label: Columbia
description: When Odd Future tumbled out of L.A. in 2010, the skilled-beyond-his-years Earl Sweatshirt tipped them into the spotlight, but just as the collective took off he vanished. Three years after his first mixtape, Sweatshirt uses his Columbia debut to convey a more varied palette of emotions. As comebacks go, it’s shockingly insular and unassuming.

title: Better Unsung
label: Lightwave
description: Los Angeles "electro shoe-goth" band Delta Mirror's followup to 2010's Machines That Listen is an ambitious record that finds frontman Chris Acosta in the role of a solo artist, despite enlisting his Machines-era players, as well as Seattle production team Blue Sky Black Death and Anticon co-founder Alias.

title: Slow Walkers
label: Peak Oil
description: Liz Harris' music as Grouper is often intensely private, a feeling she's amplified tenfold on this debut collaboration with Australian musician (and Room40 label head) Lawrence English. The instrumental, drone-based work Slow Walkers feels continuous and meditative, leaning heavily on repetition and the eerie ambience for which Harris is known.

title: Bitchitronics
label: Drag City
description: Bitchin Bajas, which began as the project of Chicago's Cooper Crain, specializes in the kind of calmly interstellar music that feels unconnected to time, space, or trends. Bitchitronics, their fourth proper album, is a serene cloud of hovering tones and near-zero motion, full of sounds that feel so good that they feel like events in themselves.

title: Flourish//Perish
label: Full Time Hobby
description: If Montreal indie rockers Braids' debut Native Speaker drew its power from being the proverbial tip of the iceberg, Flourish // Perish is the iceberg itself, impressive and monolithic. It’s an interesting and daring turn for Braids, retaining the complicated, prog-like arrangements of their past while working within the textures of IDM and minimal techno.

title: Loud City Song
label: Domino
description: L.A. avant-pop musician Julia Holter's mesmerizing third album is her interpretation of Gigi-- the musical and the original 1944 novella. The collection's learned and erudite, but not in a way that talks down to the listener: Loud City Song is breezy, contemporarily resonant, and flutteringly alive. It's her first record for Domino, and the one most likely to turn skeptics to believers.

title: We Knew It Was Not Going to Be Like This
label: Fire
description: On their second LP, the once-sunny Auckland indie-rockers Surf City showcase a growing affinity for discordant frequencies and motorik rhythms. We Knew It Was Not Going to Be Like This also offers a modernity-shunning mission statement to go with the slop pop.

title: Pura Vida Conspiracy
label: ATO
description: On Gogol Bordello's first LP in three years, frontman Eugene Hütz doesn't just deliver his lines, he devours them. Musically, Pura Vida Conspiracy feels like the fullest musical expression of his band's borderless sound since 2005's Steve Albini-recorded Gypsy Punks.

title: Versions
label: Sacred Bones
description: Versions, a collaboration with a string quartet led by J.G. Thirlwell, recasts some of Nika Roza Danilov's best songs in an orchestral setting. Danilova's powerful voice is still the focal point, but it's given a different cast by the neo-classical arrangements.

title: Mutazione: Italian Electronic & New Wave Underground 1980 - 1988
label: Strut
description: Strut’s new Mutazione: Italian Electronic & New Wave Underground 1980-1988 offers a compilation based on the too-good-to-be-true music scene in 1980s Italy, an experimental period that drew as much from Throbbing Gristle and Suicide as it does Foucault and Sartre.

title: Moon Tides
label: Memphis Industries
description: Pure Bathing Culture is a band that's steeped in the past, though the enduring effect of their debut Moon Tides is one of disorientation rather than nostalgia.

title: Dour Candy
label: Backwoodz Studioz
description: Rapper Billy Woods recorded a grip of tracks with Cannibal Ox's Vordul Mega on his 2003 debut, but has remained obscure. His latest, with production from Blockhead and a feature from Aesop Rock, finds his distinctive vision intact.

title: Dual EP
label: Young Turks
description: The 24-year-old South Londoner Sampha Sisay lent either his voice to nearly every track on SBTRKT's 2011 self-titled debut. After spending time as an integral part of the UK producer's live show, and collaborating with the likes of Jessie Ware and Drake, he's stepping out on his own with this deeply personal EP.

title: I Hate Music
label: Merge
description: The indie rock veterans return with their second album since their almost decade-long layoff. While the punchy hooks and uptempo shouters are still here, the album as a whole is a shade darker, focusing on personal loss and the passage of time.

title: Waterdrawn
label: Fluff and Gravy
description: The Horse’s Ha is the long-running collaboration of Eleventh Dream Day/Freakwater stalwart Janet Bean and singer/guitarist James Elkington. Their second album in 10 years is a stripped down collection, but one that's always changing.

title: The Affliction
label: In the Red
description: Following a six-year hiatus, Jered Gummere, the ex-frontman for Chicago garage rockers the Ponys, returns with a new band, one also featuring members of Mannequin Men and the 1900s.

title: The Word As Power
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: The first-ever vocal-oriented album from dark ambient pioneer Brian Williams, aka Lustmord, features contributions from Tool’s Maynard James Keenan and Jarboe. It's an architectural wonder, an album that feels strangely interactive and dynamic, as though its music was never meant to be final.

title: To the Happy Few
label: Captured Tracks
description: Reunited L.A. noise-pop outfit Medicine married shoegaze’s aggressive guitar turbulence and dream pop’s phantasmagoric hookiness on 1993’s The Buried Life, a record that sounded out of place at the time. Their new To the Happy Few, made with the same exact formula, now sounds perfectly situated at the leading edge of rock tastes.

title: Mark Kozelek and Desertshore
label: Caldo Verde
description: This collaboration with Desertshore-- a band featuring former Red House Painters and Sun Kil Moon members-- is Kozelek’s fourth full-length release of 2013, and arguably his best.

title: Back on the Planet
label: Brainfeeder
description: L.A. beatmaker Ras G is firmly in the tradition of the scene's most out-there producers. Back on the Planet is filled with soothing arrangements of gently pulsing drums, echo-blurred keys, and the occasional sub-bass boom.

title: Move Way EP
label: R&S
description: Drum and bass pioneer Darren White-- aka dBridge-- has been at it long after the genre went through its initial early cycle. That's afforded him the sort of later-career freedom, an opportunity he makes the most of with his new Move Way EP.

title: Home
label: Asylum
description: London dance-pop quartet Rudimental earned a #1 British debut on the heels of two chart-topping hits, "Feel the Love" and "Waiting All Night". Their debut album's dozen tracks are stuffed to the brim with disparate parts and unfold in unexpected ways.

title: Filthy EP
label: Ninja Tune
description: The UK producer Kevin Martin's teaser to Angels & Devils, his first LP as the Bug since 2008's excellent London Zoo, is a five-song EP that features guest spots from Danny Brown, Kiki Hitomi, Flowdan, and Daddy Freddy.

title: Paracosm
label: Sub Pop
description: Four years after “Feel It All Around” defined chillwave, Paracosm presents Ernest Greene as a man without a movement, someone whose music can no longer be used to project opinions about a larger trend. Produced again by Ben H. Allen, the album's instrumentation sloshes around in lush, warm reverb and palpable bass frequencies.

title: Missing Monuments
label: Dirtnap
description: New Orleans' King Louie Bankston is a veteran of many rock sounds, but his most recent project, Missing Monuments, finds Bankston returning to his formative power-pop. His band's latest self-titled album explores a more soulful expression of power-pop timelessness, if not always an even one.

title: Ritual Tradition Habit
label: Boompa
description: The Belle Game aren’t trying to fool anyone: influences like Arcade Fire, Broken Social Scene, Feist, Grizzly Bear are prominently listed on their Facebook page*. Ritual Tradition Habit* proudly manifests the effect of those bands, delivering a batch of accessible, confident indie rock.

title: Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros
label: Gentlemen of the Road
description: On their third album, Edward Sharpe & the Magnetic Zeros take the "all you need is love" platitudes to a baffling and ultimately nauseating extreme.

title: Deformed Worship
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: The deceptively sunny-named post-punk/black metal belligerents Raspberry Bulbs began as the solo project of Marco del Rio, known as He Who Crushes Teeth in the corrosive BM duo Bone Awl. On the band's excellent first release as a five piece, featuring ex-members of Rorschach and Italian Horn, he's able to concentrate solely on his murderous bark.

title: All That I Hold Dear
label: Stones Throw
description: If you like cerebral rap music, Queens rapper Homeboy Sandman has been your man for some time now. His new album, All That I Hold Dear, utilizes sparkling soul beats and verses that are slightly more modulated than his usual darts of staccato.

title: Vehicle
label: Flying Nun
description: The Clean’s debut full-length, now reissued on vinyl by Captured Tracks with a bonus live EP, came after they’d already been legends for almost a decade. After the rough and ready four-track recordings that marked their early singles and EPs, Vehicle was very much like a studio creation, but the fuller production didn't harm the performances.

title: The Nextwave Sessions
label: Frenchkiss
description: Bloc Party's new EP The Nextwave Sessions shares that jumbled sense of purpose with its predecessor Four, but exists as a less scattered and more consistent document of the band's style-sampling present.

title: Imps of Perversion
label: Sacred Bones
description: Post-punk quartet Pop. 1280's new album, Imps of Perversion, showcases a more polished approach. But compared to the apocalyptic clamor of 2012's The Horror, that same crispness and clarity works against the band’s attempts to dredge up the dread.

title: Hobo Rocket
label: Modular
description: Pond shares two members with Tame Impala and is likely to be considered a side project even though Hobo Rocket is their fifth album. They also share a sound, focusing on fuzzed-out effects-heavy psych jams.

title: Somerset Avenue Tracks (1992-1995)
label: Planet Mu
description: Combing the early part of electronic musician and Planet Mu founder Mike Paradinas'-- aka µ-Ziq-- career, Somerset Avenue Tracks is as raw as you’d expect from an artist just starting to find himself, but it's strong enough to stand with the best work that he’s done.

title: Space Mirror
label: Kranky
description: Ken Camden spends his time away from drone rock outfit Implodes with a solo career that demonstrates a fondness for sparse, repeating figures. His new LP, Space Mirror, has a softer hew to the sound, laid out in a cottony expanse that largely replaces the sharper edges of 2010's Lethargy & Repercussion.

title: The Complete LHI Recordings
label: Light in the Attic
description: Light in the Attic’s compilation of tracks by 1960s female vocal group Honey Ltd. collects every song the Los Angeles-via-Detroit quartet recorded for Lee Hazlewood’s imprint, which means it collects every song they ever made.

title: Dysnomia
label: Thirsty Ear
description: While Brooklyn's Dawn of Midi shares the instrumental makeup of famous jazz aligments, their new album Dysnomia focuses on rhythm and dismantling jazz with the tools that built it.

title: Joke in the Hole
label: DFA
description: Black Dice member Eric Copeland's latest solo venture (and return to DFA) is a series of samples and beats that features a lighter touch than most of his band's records, with a fondness for pop forms weaved into the confusion.

title: Remixes
label: Temporary Residence
description: Remixes-- a reimagined version of Nigel Godrich's Ultraísta project's debut album with remixes from Four Tet, David Lynch and more-- is more like an unraveling, an opportunity to peel back the high-beam synths that smother so many Ultraísta tracks and expose the darker undercurrents and sense of unrest bubbling underneath.

title: Tempest
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: On their debut album Tempest, the Oakland death doom quartet Lycus sand down the rough edges of their 2011 demo and embrace a unique take on European funeral doom. The quartet refrain from histrionic, death-worshipping self-hatred and instead embrace a more cosmic, organic take on sorrow.

title: Tides End
label: Captured Tracks
description: Brooklyn-based musician Sean Kilfoyle-- who records as Minks-- has expressed a desire to move away from debut LP By The Hedge's "wall of sound" toward something more direct. On Tides End, Minks' vision goes awry from the beginning.

title: The A&R EP
label: Pleasure Masters
description: A&R, Annie’s comeback EP, stands for Annie and Richard X, but it's also a fitting pun: These five tracks, two of which feature writing credits for Little Boots and Hannah Robinson, match the Norwegian pop singer to just the sort of repertoire the public’s currently demanding.

title: Forestelevision
label: Translation Loss
description: The third album by the Seattle quartet Lesbian is one 44-minute track, during which the band manages to move without pause from aching funeral doom to arching classic thrash, from acid-washed electric jazz to acrobatic prog-rock, from ambling stoner rumble to assailant death metal. And that’s merely a sample.

title: Lenses
label: Captured Tracks
description: Los Angeles duo Soft Metals approach their music with the loose conceptual framework of avant-garde sound artists. Their second album, which dives deeper into the hallucinogenic soundscapes of their previous work, comes off like a proggy synth-pop record that wants to get treated like a sculpture.

title: Loftus
label: Jealous Butcher
description: In 1995, the Chicago-based band Red Red Meat and the Brooklyn-based band Rex concluded a tour and decided to record together. It seemed appropriate that the artifact, which was released in 2000 and sounded like something that has been pulled from underneath a rotting log, would quietly fade away. But now it returns with this vinyl/digital reissue.

title: Dawning
label: Translation Loss
description: For a decade, the Ohio post-metal band Mouth of the Architect has largely been ghettoized to cult status. Dawning, their first record in five years, is also their best work to date, a fully realized resurrection that suggests a breakthrough.

title: Sleep of Reason
label: Ninja Tune
description: Raffertie is the latest in a line of dance music producers to move to subtle and grown-up R&B-ish music. His new album Sleep of Reason contains reflective songwriting and carefully contained outbursts.

title: II
label: Mute
description: Berlin's Apparat (aka Sascha Ring) and Modeselektor (the duo of Gernot Bronsert and Sebastian Szary) return for a second album. The major differences between II and their self-titled debut is that their sonic sensibilities have grown more refined and compelling, and that the world of electronic music has just about caught up to them.

title: Shadows
label: Profound Lore
description: Morne has, to date, used its discography like a very public workshop. As its dimly lit name and colony-of-cobwebs cover suggests, the Boston metal quartet's third album, Shadows, finds them slinking deeper into their molten doom.

title: Circumambulation
label: Relapse
description: The pace has quickened a little for Texas "doomgaze" trio True Widow on Circumambulation, the band's debut for metal enclave Relapse Records and a record that aims to expand their audience.

title: PARTYNEXTDOOR
label: October's Very Own
description: Toronto-based singer and producer PARTYNEXTDOOR recently signed with Drake's OVO Sound imprint, and his debut mixtape abounds with homespun beats that turn radio rap tropes inside out and easy melodicism.

title: Tiny Rebels
label: Empty Cellar
description: The Cairo Gang are best known in the last few years for their work with Bonnie "Prince" Billy. On this mini-LP, Emmett Kelly's project sounds beamed in directly from 1966, just as psychedelia started creeping its way toward folk-rock.

title: Knots
label: Big Scary Monsters
description: Crash of Rhinos' second album, Knots, is the result of endless practice in the time since the UK band's 2011's Distal and a formidable inspirational spark. Knots is an intuitive, rigorously plotted record hinting at genre transcendence.

title: The Night's Gambit
label: Iron Works
description: The Brooklyn-based MC comes into his own on his third album. It's hard to separate the stark tone of Ka's voice and narrative from the equally stark mood music he embeds it in. As a rapper/producer, he has that finely-tuned awareness of how a track works from every angle.

title: Around
label: Graveface
description: On their new EP, Whirr forgo the relatively tight strictures of 2012's Pipe Dreams and position themselves within the realm of NorCal bands like Palms, Weekend, and Deafheaven that have been using intimidation tactics to coax beauty out of their guitars.

title: Underworlds
label: 20 Buck Spin
description: On their third album, Mammoth Grinder, who share members with Hatred Surge and the now defunct Iron Age, offer a manic blend of death metal, crust, and punk. It's a savage collection that finds the Austin quartet coming into their own as genre-bashing geniuses.

title: Ruby Red
label: Merge
description: After two albums of solo recording, the Love Language's Stuart McLamb enlisted a small army of collaborators on his third album. McLamb seems to be relishing the chance to get outside of his head, making music that is gorgeous and unashamedly fun.

title: The Argument
label: Domino
description: While his former Hüsker Dü bandmate Bob Mould has remained visible, Grant Hart has recorded only sporadically. His new The Argument-- a take on John Milton’s Paradise Lost as adapted by William S. Burroughs-- is impressively diverse and dense.

title: Live at Maida Vale
label: Relapse
description: A month before their 2012 tour bus accident, Baroness stopped at the BBC’s studio at Maida Vale to record an interview and amped-up renditions of four Yellow & Green tracks. Amid last year’s dual hubbubs about the band's newly sharpened rock songs and that August crash, this limited-edition, one-sided LP preserves the memory of the pugnacious, strapping quartet at the center of it all.

title: In Search
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Songwriter Chance Martin's 1981 cult classic debut album, In Search, was so overlooked when it was released that it may as well have never existed. A new reissue revisits In Search, a record that proffers a high-concept hodgepodge of loverman soul, outlaw country and blaxpoitation funk that sounds just as bizarre today as it no doubt did 32 years ago.

title: Indigo Summer
label: self-released
description: LA-based R&B singer Nylo has supported herself for a while as a graphic designer and session musician, so she has a feel for cool and craft. Her second mixtape keeps her phenomenal voice and savvy ear for production front and center, but the record shows its hand a little more.

title: Aerotropolis
label: Hyperdub
description: Ikonika's new album Aerotropolis is a stated tribute to the old-school freestyle house and synthpop jams that soundtracked Sara Abdel-Hamid's 80s youth, a record thats feels like an innovative rulebreaker hitting the reset button and starting a completely new persona from scratch.

title: Body Music
label: Vagrant
description: The UK duo of vocalist Aluna Francis and producer George Reid make future-pop songs that mix their love of old Timbaland and Neptunes-produced hits with an indie-leaning sensibility. Their full-length debut shares songs with their well-received EP and further streamlines their sound.

title: High Beams EP
label: Fool's Gold
description: RL Grimes is the grittier, more ominous alter-ego of 22-year-old producer Henry Steinway, who makes big-room EDM as Clockwork. His new EP also showcases one of the producer’s greatest talents: his ability to restructure songs entirely without losing the drama of soaring dance melodies.

title: Nothing Hype
label: Wyrd
description: Copenhagen's Nick Eriksen, aka Taragana Pyjarama, makes electronic music as playfully elaborate as his moniker. Following his fine-detailed Kompakt debut Tipped Bowls he's releasing the "mini-LP" Nothing Hype on his own Wyrd imprint.

title: Sunken
label: Autumn Tone
description: On Sunken, the newly re-released mini-LP by Chicago garage rock quartet Twin Peaks, the group has perfected the kind of songwriting that puts you in a practiced, happy headlock, drawing from acts like the Replacements and the Flamin' Groovies.

title: Partygoing
label: Merge
description: Stephin Merritt's third album with the Future Bible Heroes, the first since 2002's Eternal Youth, is available either individually or as part of a remastered collection of the synth-pop outfit's back catalogue. It's an oddball record full of moments that ought to make Merritt devotees knowingly nudge their neighbors.

title: Stranger Than Fiction
label: Breadwinners Association
description: The Louisiana rapper's follow-up to the excellent The Luca Brasi Story finds him world-weary in all the spots where he was starry-eyed and reflective. While the pop hooks are played down, Gates' knack for detailed, despairing storytelling cogently picks up the slack.

title: Our Own Masters
label: Volcom
description: Valient Thorr probably remain best known for their back story-- that the five members hail from Venus, but crash-landed on Earth where they've been stuck ever since, unable to fix their ship. On the heavy Our Own Masters, they get in touch with more earthly, relatable problems and emotions.

title: Vivid Green
label: Alpha Pup
description: Nobody's output this far has ridden more on the personalities of collaborators and scene compatriots than any specific character statement of his own. On his new Vivid Green, he further explores the pleasures of subtlety and long-soak immersion with help from Baths, Cedric Bixler-Zavala and others.

title: Love Your Dum and Mad
label: Apollo
description: Nadine Shah has been described as the imagined union of PJ Harvey and Nick Cave, but the British vocalist's actual Pakistani lineage sheds more light. Growing up, her father sang Urdu ghazals around the house, a form of Arabic poetry about love and loss-- most every song on her dark, intense debut is about being undone by love's true nature.

title: Fantasy
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The duo consisting of Black Mountain vocalist Amber Webber and drummer Joshua Wells has had a certain amount in common with Webber's main outfit, with tinges of doomy, occasionally inscrutable, psychedelia. Their third album adds electronics and slicker production to the mix.

title: Jinx
label: Slumberland
description: Expanding from a trio to a quartet, the shadowy Brooklyn-via-San Francisco post-punk band's second LP features a strong palette of blacks and grays but, unlike their 2010 debut, Jinx also has a reflective, acrylic gloss to it. Weekend are making lucid, pop-conscious moves.

title: The Bardo Story
label: Weird World
description: Baltimore musician Michael Collins had to give up his Run DMT moniker to a dubstep crew of the same name, but the music he's creating as Salvia Plath is suited to the change: On The Bardo Story, he's shed his early chillwave tendencies, bringing his 60s psych influences into sharper focus.

title: Return to Annihilation
label: Relapse
description: The prolific Chicago-and-Baltimore metallic noise trio Locrian's Relapse debut is their most provocative and engaging album to date. The 50-minute Return to Annihilation is intrinsically elusive, with twists so compelling and layers so deep that each listen reveals a half-dozen new facets.

title: Palms
label: Ipecac
description: Palms is a partnership between Deftones vocalist Chino Moreno and three members of Isis. They've been dubbed "dream metal" thanks to their reputations, but Palms never really rocks physically-- the six exploratory songs here take you on a spiritual rather than visceral journey.

title: Street Punk
label: Hardly Art
description: Much like a recent move by his friend and collaborator Nobunny, Seth Bogart's Hunx and his Punx make a sudden turn for a much more pointedly aggro sound with Street Punk. The versatile record also features Shannon and the Clams' Shannon Shaw.

title: Melbourne
label: Fat Possum
description: This promising debut album from the young North Carolina-based singer/songwriter mixes the lysergic creepiness of Syd Barrett with more straight-forward and hooky guitar jams indebted to indie rock.

title: Destruction in Yr Soul
label: Graveface
description: Destruction in Yr Soul is Hospital Ships' third full-length, and it aims higher and resonates more deeply than 2011's Lonely Twin. Bandleader Jordan Geiger even manages to stir some of the grand feelings of his idols: the Flaming Lips, Built to Spill, and Arcade Fire.

title: Love Is the Law
label: Burger
description: White Fang offshoot the Memories make short, punchy rock songs about love and smoking weed. Love Is the Law, their follow-up to the enjoyable The Memories, proves that there’s a razor-thin line between sweetly simple and facepalmingly dumb.

title: Electric
label: Kobalt
description: Last September's weary, autumnal Elysium didn't offer much hope for the future of Pet Shop Boys. So, it's a surprise that Electric is their most immediate, jubilant record in at least a decade.

title: All Hail West Texas
label: Merge
description: The Mountain Goats' 2003 LP All Hail West Texas is a lonely album, a product of idle time and summer boredom recorded alone, quickly, in an empty house. A new reissue on Merge includes thorough liner notes from John Darnielle and unreleased material.

title: Ghil
label: Editions Mego
description: For Ghil, cellist Okkyung Lee travelled around Oslo with Norwegian noise musician Lasse Marhaug, who recorded her thrilling improvisations with a cheap mic and a vintage 1976 tape deck. She then let Marhaug edit down nearly three hours of her work and sequence the results without hearing the full source material herself.

title: Tiden
label: Bureau B
description: Electronic musician Hans-Joachim Roedelius, a founding member of Cluster and Harmonia, has worked with so many notable collaborators that even the most ardent krautrock obsessive probably doesn't own a complete set of his works. On Tiden, he teams up with occassional collaborator Stefan Schneider for an inquisitive, exploratory collection.

title: Chewed Corners
label: Planet Mu
description: Planet Mu's Mike Paradinas has never reached the heights of acclaim afforded to his IDM contemporaries like Aphex Twin, but his importance in shaping the style is indisputable. Chewed Corners, his first µ-Ziq LP in six years, is brimming with optimism and ideas.

title: Slow Focus
label: ATP
description: On Slow Focus, Fuck Buttons' first album in four years, Ben Power and Andy Hung remain devoted to forbidding, elemental sensations. Their slow-moving pieces inspire the kinds of big feelings that double as reminders of our smallness, and they've never sounded this massive before.

title: Deceiver of the Gods
label: Metal Blade
description: During the last two decades, Sweden's Amon Amarth has released nine albums of headstrong Viking metal. The best of those have felt both urgent and addictive, but on Deceiver of the Gods, it feels as if the long-running quintet has now settled into the complacency and comfort of their reputation.

title: Celestial Soul Portrait
label: Numero Group
description: This new compilation assembled by Numero Group functions as a highlight reel of Greek-born, San Francisco-dwelling composer Iasos' 30-year-plus career in new age ambient music, which emanated from a similar psychedelic discipline to Terry Riley.

title: Tonight You Look Like a Spider
label: Joyful Noise
description: Scratch Acid and the Jesus Lizard frontman David Yow's new solo album Tonight You Look Like a Spider-- a record 15 years in the making-- is mostly instrumental, alternately brilliant and terrible, sometimes focused, at other times hopelessly rambling.

title: Dear Mark J Mulcahy I Love You
label: Fire
description: Given the death of his wife in 2008 and his subsequent focus on his family in favor of public work, it would be understandable if onetime Miracle Legion frontman Mark Mulcahy’s first full album in almost a decade was calm and somber. But Dear Mark J. Mulcahy I Love You is marked by its bright, easygoing, and often upbeat spirit.

title: Human Overdose
label: Iron Lung
description: Austin/Houston grindcore trio Hatred Surge, featuring past and current members of Power Trip, Mammoth Grinder, Iron Age, and Trap Them, released Human Overdose during this year's Chaos in Tejas festival in Austin. It's their burliest, most focused record to date.

title: About Farewell
label: Rusted Blue
description: Portland folkie Alela Diane's musical co-pilot on her last record was guitarist Tom Bevitori, also her husband at the time. That marriage ended*,* prompting a return to the stark guitar-and-voice arrangements of her early work on About Farewell.

title: Where Does This Door Go
label: Republic
description: Mayer Hawthorne's got retro-soul revivalist tags stapled on to him, thanks to a hip-hop fiend's sense of vintage soul. On his new album, Where Does This Door Go, Hawthorne cedes his usual production duties to an all-star cast and adds new dimensions to his repertoire.

title: Nocturnes
description: William Basinski's new release Nocturnes shows that the ambient artist hasn't let the weight of his most lauded piece, The Disintegration Loops, overwhelm him. On Nocturnes, Basinski makes his past an integral part of the present.

title: Unreal
label: ATP
description: The ex-Yuck frontman Daniel Blumberg's first album as Hebronix is a hangover/breakup record produced by Royal Trux’s Neil Hagerty. Unreal features frazzled, fuzz-flecked guitar tones and marathon track lengths and comes off as decidedly less wholesome than any of Blumberg’s previous work.

title: Stills
label: Dead Oceans
description: On their sophomore album, the Denver-via-Chicago duo amplify the darker undercurrents of their sound and switch on the strobe lights. The approach is reminiscent of 80s goth acts like Love & Rockets and Jesus and Mary Chain, bands who streamlined their approach and graduated to the summer-amphitheater circuit.

title: Evolution
label: Orchard
description: Though Detroit's Slum Village has suffered many hardships, their music, for the most part, has been consistent. Their new album Evolution-- which features only one founding member-- has trouble living up to their older work.

title: Crisis
label: Dropping Gems
description: Portland vocalist-composer Natasha Kmeto has been compared to Maya Jane Coles, Grimes, and Jessie Ware, though she has as much in common with James Blake and How to Dress Well. Her proper full-length debut features precision production, straightforward melodies, plainspoken lyrics, and a new sense of urgency.

title: Home Life
label: Underwater Peoples
description: The rigors of touring resulted in Andrew Cedermark parting ways with Titus Andronicus. His second solo LP, the warm, shuffling, country-paced Home Life, finds him playing up the existential and philosophical issues that make “home” one of the most powerful and commonplace concepts in pop music.

title: Nothing Can Hurt Me
label: Omnivore
description: Nothing Can Hurt Me is the soundtrack for the new Big Star documentary of the same name. It contains unheard, alternate mixes from #1 Record, rough mixes from Sister Lovers, and other special mixes created for the movie. Together, they more or less function as a solid best-of.

title: Tarot
label: 100% Silk
description: Brooklyn-based electronic musician Alex Burkat is still the guy that's caught up in the jubilation of clubland, but the tracks that make up his debut EP Tarot hint at how those experiences stimulate reflection as well as hands-in-the-air euphoria.

title: Music for Objects EP
label: Paper Bag
description: Montreal producer/composer Mike Silver's new EP, a companion to last year's Exercises, was inspired by unspectacular everyday objects, as well as Wim Wenders' 1989 documentary Notebook on Cities and Clothes. On it, he uses saxophone, piano, marimba, and other instruments to deepen his electronic palette.

title: The Big Dream
label: Sunday Best
description: The film director's second full-length solo album continues with the smokey blues mood and creepy atmosphere of 2011's Crazy Clown Time. A digital bonus track features guest vocals from Lykke Li.

title: Old Mornings Dawn
label: Napalm
description: Old Mornings Dawn is the Austrian epic metal band Summoning's seventh album, and first since 2006's Oath Bound. The core sound hasn't changed-- Burzum and Emperor's impact is still obvious and there are plenty of keyboards, programmed drums, and pagan chants and choruses-- but they've amped up their guitar lines while genuflecting towards past triumphs.

title: Time Off
label: Paradise of Bachelors
description: Steve Gunn is a sometime-guitarist in Kurt Vile's Violators, and one half of the Gunn-Truscinski Duo. Time Off is a collection of six loose, spiraling guitar songs that give more than they ask: generous compositions, gently presented, recalling the Grateful Dead, JJ Cale, and Bert Jansch.

title: Bass Drum of Death
label: Innovative Leisure
description: Mississippi native John Barrett wrote and recorded Bass Drum of Death's self-titled sophomore album by himself. From its power chord drive to its garage rock immediacy to the smoke billowing out of his mouth on the cover, it offers a natural extension of his 2011 debut.

title: Summer Knights
label: Cinematic
description: One of the most surprising mixtapes of 2012 was made by a Flatbush teenager named Jo-Vaughn Scott a.k.a. Joey Bada$$, but the enthusiastic momentum that buoyed 1999 is missing on his second mixtape, Summer Knights.

title: Major Arcana
label: Carpark
description: On their proper debut, Speedy Ortiz join a small club of young indie rock bands writing lyrics that are actually worth poring over, but the charms here extend beyond frontwoman Sadie Dupuis' clever and biting wordplay. The 1990s-indebted guitar crunch and quaking rhythms are a perfect match for her dark wit.

title: Spiritoso
label: Anti-
description: Originally a Record Store Day exclusive, Spiritoso documents a series of shows Calexico performed in Germany with the Vienna Radio Symphony Orchestra and the Deutsches Filmorchester Babelsberg. It underscores how far the duo have come in a decade, not to mention all that's been lost and gained along the way.

title: Southeastern
label: Thirty Tigers
description: Though former Drive-By Truckers member Jason Isbell's previous solo albums displayed promise with songwriting standouts, his new LP Southeastern is his most gripping and most personal album to date.

title: Embracism
label: XL
description: The debut album by Kirin J Callinan investigates the Australian solo artist's predilection for the awkward, scarred, and imperfect sides of human bodies and emotions. Between the erratic shrapnel of percussion, jagged guitar, and Callinan’s serrated vocals, Embracism is an album you'll feel.

title: Ciara
label: Epic
description: Ciara touches on just about every facet of the R&B singer's style to date. While she’s a more versatile, accomplished singer than when she started, her appeal, especially on ballads, remains essentially unchanged.

title: Melt Yourself Down
label: Leaf
description: Melt Yourself Down rises from the ashes of Acoustic Ladyland, an incendiary ensemble led by British saxophonist Pete Wareham that played free-improv jazz as if it were hard-charging rock music. The band's self-titled debut is direct and infectious, jostling with harmonic and rhythmic allusions to Nubia, the Middle East, Latin America.

title: Swisher
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Last year's Blondes, a collection of singles, found the Brooklyn-based duo offering up tech house at its most unabashedly pretty. Follow-up Swisher builds from that release, establishing the ultimate core of their aesthetic somewhere deeper and altogether more mysterious.

title: ESGN
label: ESGN
description: On recent efforts like Cold Day in Hell and Baby Face Killa, Gary, Indiana rapper Freddie Gibbs managed to widen his appeal by branching into more soulful territory. His latest, ESGN, finds the rapper back working in a more familiar lane.

title: Me Moan
label: Sub Pop
description: Daughn Gibson's 2012 album, All Hell, was an intriguing confluence of sampling and songwriting; something akin to Odelay if it was culled entirely from the kind of country cassettes available at truckstops. On Me Moan, Gibson's first proper Sub Pop release*,* Gibson attempts to maintain the immediate draw of his authoritative vocals and perspective.

title: Ruby Pins
label: M'Lady's
description: Drummer/singer Lillian Maring's full-time gig is as a member of Grass Widow. With her solo project Ruby Pins, she steps away from the collective process to embrace her darker creative impulses. Her debut is a lo-fi, surreal collection of songs.

title: Sub Contra
label: Thrill Jockey
description: People of the North is a side project from Oneida's Kid Millions and Bobby Matador, a duo now onto their third album together, their first for Thrill Jockey. Sub Contra is a short set of instrumental jams with a purposeful looseness in the playing, often underpinned by a sense of gloom that loosely ties it to the last couple of Oneida records.

title: Without Your Love
label: Nihjgt Feelings
description: With his debut full-length, oOoOO mastermind Chris Dexter’s ear for dramatics is stronger than ever. He hasn’t strayed from the dimly lit brooding that took over oOoOO and Our Love Is Hurting Us, but in the years since witch house has moved out of the spotlight, the musician has figured out what he wants to do with his sound: go pop.

title: Honey Locust Honky Tonk
label: GBV
description: Given Robert Pollard's pedigree and prolificacy, it should surprise no-one that Honey Locust Honky Tonk is a good record. But what is surprising is quite how good it is, his best and most focused in some time. Pollard burrows deeper into his beloved classic rock, and somehow discovers new modes of expression.

title: The Remixes, Vol. 1
label: Ultra Music
description: *The Remixes Vol. 1 * makes the producer's choppily momentous and joyously abrasive sense of rhythm the focal point. The collection, which features Kid Cudi and Travis Barker and AraabMuzik's take on a Skrillex remix, feels like a mission statement.

title: Corps Exquis
label: New Amsterdam
description: Played by the five-piece ensemble Transit (plus guests including Julia Holter) Corps Exquis is an album of compositions by the Paris-born composer Daniel Wohl. It rallies together a tiny army's worth of interesting sounds, a zone of confusion between digital glitch and bow-on-string screech.

title: Blaze Colour Burn
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Mouse on Mars' Jan St. Werner has made solo recordings under various guises before, but here he steps out under his own name for the first time. Blaze Colour Burn is the inaugural release in Thrill Jockey's Fiepblatter series, which focuses on field recordings, improvisation, and other elements drawn from the margins of sound.

title: Live at Bestival 2012
label: Sunday Best
description: Live at Bestival captures New Order's 2012 headline set at the British festival. Its release benefits charity, making it a commendable venture. Still, its placing in New Order's discography is likely to be insignificant-- 2011's Live at the London Troxy already documented this incarnation of the group, and a very similar tracklisting.

title: Drillary Clinton
label: Lawless
description: The Chicago drill scene mainstay with the brashly funny style steps out on a new mixtape, featuring production from BlockOnDaTrakk and guests including King Louie.

title: Contact
label: Audraglint
description: Chicago's Jeremiah Chrome and Brandon Boom originally started making music to emulate R&B super-producer the-Dream. They released one EP under that template, with which their debut full-length all but breaks: Contact's retro-futurism flits between drum & bass, footwork, two-step, and, occasionally, R&B.

title: The Inheritors
label: Border Community
description: The UK producer's second album combines the open-field psychedelia of Cluster and Popul Vuh with a healthy amount of Boards of Canada's dusty gaze, oscillating between buzzy pastoral beauty and harsh rhythmic duress.

title: Ecstasy & Release
label: Groovement
description: Tiago Miranda has made sunkissed Balearica as part of Mendes & Alçada, and leftfield disco, acid, and psychedelic dub house for the likes of Italians Do it Better, Ene, Internasjonal Spesial, and DFA. This is his debut full-length effort, uncredited, and unbeholden to any one genre.

title: Planta
label: SQE
description: TV on the Radio's David Sitek produced the Brazilian band's fourth album, which is gloriously cheesy in all the right places. Unfortunately, the departure of Adriano Cintra and his subsequent revelations punctured CSS' good-time club kid image, which they struggle to uphold here.

title: For Years
label: R&S
description: As Airhead, Rob McAndrews makes low-key electronic music that never lets you forget the human presence behind it, in a similar fashion to his frequent collaborator James Blake. His debut, For Years, is rooted in Dilla-like hip-hop abstractions and a subdued take on post-rock.

title: Run the Jewels
label: Unknown
description: In 2012, El-P released Cancer for Cure and Killer Mike the El-P-produced R.A.P. Music. These excellent albums shared the kind of catharsis-fueled defiance that career no-sellout vets live and breathe. The MCs' new collaborative record, Run the Jewels, is a distilled take on everything that made last year's records such an event, with all the chrome ripped off and upholstery pulled out so it'll run faster, louder, nastier.

title: Hailu Mergia and His Classical Instrument
label: Awesome Tapes From Africa
description: Hailu Mergia was once the keyboardist for Walias Band, whose 1977 recording "Muziqawi Silt" is a defining piece of Ethiopia's musical history. Walias broke up in the early 80s after a trip to the U.S., where Mergia stayed. A few years later, he made this album, merging the sounds of his youth with modern technology, making for striking, unusual results.

title: Manifest Decimation
label: Southern Lord
description: Before Power Trip released Manifest Decimation, they were one of those groups people said you needed to see live to understand. However, the new eight-song LP Manifest Decimation, their first release for Southern Lord, is such a strong collection that you could never see the Dallas crossover thrash band live and still understand what makes them special.

title: BE
label: Columbia
description: On the second album by the Liam Gallagher-helmed band, Beady Eye progress beyond the rudimentary Oasisisms of their debut by employing TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek as producer. As you'd expect, BE is more adventurous and dynamic than Different Gear-- but is it better for it?

title: Agony Defined
label: A389
description: The debut album from Baltimore teens Noisem takes a basic thrash template, adds a generous measure of death metal, and hammers it without mercy. Agony Defined is a lean record that calls to mind earlier Slayer and, more surprisingly, Iceage.

title: Sob Story
label: Wichita
description: Girls' J.R. White produced the second album by the swoony Yorkshire band, allowing Louis Jones to expand Spectrals' sound. Sob Story is at its best when Jones delivers brisk, bright rock with endearing hooks, offset by his distinct, indelible croon.

title: The Visitor
label: Cómeme
description: The Visitor deepens Matias Aguayo's dependence on his voice as he steers away from merely assisting dance tracks to carrying song structures. In the past, his goofy, spontaneous-seeming persona has carried his music with ease, but here, he sounds like he's struggling at times.

title: The Gifted
label: Atlantic
description: Wale's third official album is his most sonically daring yet, pushing a classic soul and gospel sound inspired by the likes of Marvin Gaye and Stevie Wonder. What he doesn't have, however, is their knack for writing lyrics to rattle anyone's whole worldview.

title: Suicide Black Snake
label: Magic Bullet
description: Suicide Black Snake, Integrity’s fitful new LP on excellent Baltimore imprint A389, reaffirms both of Integrity’s key qualities-- that scathing attitude and cross-stitched aesthetic-- in 10 decidedly strange songs. Beneath the surface, this music reveals complicated arrangements.

title: Heart of Nowhere
label: Mercury
description: Noah and the Whale are a big draw on the European festival circuit. But a new era of blockbuster folk rock spearheaded by the likes of the Lumineers means Noah's quaint leanings risk getting lost in the crush. Heart of Nowhere attempts to address this imbalance, taking Bruce Springsteen as its blueprint.

title: One True Vine
label: Anti- / Epitaph
description: Mavis Staples' second album produced by Wilco's Jeff Tweedy traces the believer's journey from doubt-- conveyed by a reverent cover of Low's "Holy Ghost"-- to certainty, its sentiments more reflective than 2010's rousing You Are Not Alone. Compositions by Funkadelic, Nick Lowe, the Staples Sisters, and Tweedy himself also appear.

title: Olympia
label: Domino
description: On Austra's disarmingly personal second album, the Toronto band's core trio has doubled to a six-piece, bringing more layers to Katie Stelmanis' songwriting, and pushing it in a more house-inspired synth-pop direction.

title: Ideal Cities
label: Fan Death
description: Risen from the ashes of Baltimore punk mainstays Double Dagger, Roomrunner tighten the screws of their noise rock approach on Ideal Cities, putting sharper focus on Denny Bowen's sardonic vocals, and paying homage to several fellow Charm City bands.

title: Kenny Dennis LP
label: Anticon
description: The latest addition to Serengeti's records about his Kenny Dennis character-- a 1990s hardcore rap also-ran now at middle-age-- instills the comedic construction with additional pathos and extended range. Odd Nosdam provides a slate of beats that leans heavily on unsettled dissonance.

title: FOUR (Acts of Love)
label: Mute
description: Mick Harvey's second solo album since leaving the Bad Seeds comprises original material alongside covers of work by Roy Orbison, Van Morrison, and PJ Harvey (who also sings on a duet here). It oozes curdled lust, broken obsession, and morbid romanticism, and posits Harvey as a contemporary of Bill Callahan or Michael Gira.

title: Blowout Comb
label: Light in the Attic
description: Emerging from hip-hop's brief and fruitful collision with jazz at the turn of the 1990s, Digable Planets' second album is a love letter to Brooklyn's Fort Greene neighborhood. On Blowout Comb, they made a proto-crate-digging approach feel completely organic, and integrated with their broader goal of deepening rap's connection to music history.

title: Acquitted
label: Maybach
description: Following Gunplay's release from house arrest and acquittal of a crime captured on surveillance cameras, the rapper's latest mixtape is very much part of the tradition of the post-trial rap record, though it's short on unalloyed triumph.

title: Joy One Mile
label: Rvng Intl.
description: Joy One Mile is the most comprehensive document yet of Christelle Gualdi’s newly rhythmic sound, and her most substantial release in some years. Mixed by cult German house figure Kassem Mosse, these songs' complex percussive patterns and glistening synth motifs fizz with barely restrained kinetic energy.

title: First Issue
label: Light in the Attic
description: Released mere months after the Sex Pistols’ infamous implosion, PiL's First Issue was deemed too uncommercial to release in the U.S. This Light in the Attic reissue marks the first time the band's scabrous debut album has been officially available Stateside. It features a prescient BBC interview as bonus material.

title: Watching Movies With the Sound Off
label: Rostrum
description: Watching Movies with the Sound Off is a quantum leap in artistry from Mac Miller's 2011 debut, Blue Slide Park. Featuring production from Flying Lotus, Alchemist, Clams Casino, Pharrell, and Earl Sweatshirt, and a rare Jay Electronica verse, it’s the wide-eyed kid brother of Blue Slide Park home from college extolling the virtues of meditation and salvia.

title: Antenna to the Afterworld
label: Polyvinyl
description: On Antenna to the Afterworld, Sonny Smith marries an extensive narrative about outer space and alien life with ruminations on the deaths of two close friends. It's a spiritual, cosmic collection with the alien synthesizers and acid-soaked psychedelic vocals to match.

title: Jackleg Devotional to the Heart
label: Sub Pop
description: Jackleg Devotional is the Denton, Texas-based outfit's first album in a full decade, which suggests a get-to-it-when-I-get-to-it attitude toward the creative process. It sounds as though it was built out of assorted junkyard scraps, a distinctive and unusual approach matched by Chris Flemmons' antiquated language and poetic phrasing.

title: Howlin'
label: Marathon Artists
description: The Australian duo Jagwar Ma’s gleeful debut Howlin’ evokes Madchester in its heady swirl of baggy beats, unabashed Beach Boys melodies, and charmingly silly lyrics. It's a backwards looking record about loving the present moment.

title: Ice on the Dune
label: Astralwerks
description: Empire of the Sun's follow up to their breakthrough 2008 debut Walking on a Dream was written and recorded during an endless arena-date treadmill. Now legitimately famous, the Australian duo are both more impressive and less distinctive.

title: Born Sinner
label: Roc Nation
description: J. Cole's lastest album finds the Roc Nation signee in a referential state of mind. In addition to all the name-checks, the album also features Kendrick Lamar, Amber Coffman, Miguel, and TLC.

title: The Dusted Sessions
label: Thrill Jockey
description: The third album by Oakland, CA's Date Palms rides a foundation of doom metal, psych rock, and mournful country. What separates them from their drifting contemporaries is a distinct sense of composition; these are painstakingly considered, beguiling pieces partially inspired by California's Yuba River.

title: Long Enough to Leave
label: Slumberland
description: The second album by San Francisco's the Mantles sustains an intruiguing tension between lyrics that resonate with a sense of detachment and open, outward-looking melodies that evoke R.E.M., Real Estate, and Television, without sounding like mere clones.

title: American Love
label: self-released
description: In 2011, Boston funk mob Bad Rabbits launched a quick stopgap covers series that revealed a startling versatility. Building from that, American Love finds the band eager to show off the moves they’ve learned since their debut Stick Up Kids.

title: Scott: The Collection 1967-1970
label: Interscope
description: This box set collects remastered versions of Scott Walker's first five solo albums. For those who know Walker's music through his avant-garde material from the last 20 years, these highly arranged and orchestrated pop records seems to come from another world. But the dark and strange themes were already there.

title: Saaab Stories
label: Vice
description: While Saaab Stories is Bronson’s shortest official release, it’s his most diverse and sonically interesting, finding middle ground between Blue Chips' weeded-out vibe and the more traditional cratedigging on Rare Chandeliers. Meanwhile, his lyrics are more degrading and base than ever.

title: Mansions 2
label: self-released
description: Spit's latest beat tape, Mansions 2, is the second in a series of instrumental releases that narrows in on short flashes of inspiration and strings them along for brief but engrossing moments, a transporting, psychedelic sonic travelogue.

title: The Dwell
label: UNO
description: San Fernando Valley artist Zane Reynolds takes the playful approach of acid house on his debut full-length as SFV Acid, patching together a series of 303-heavy, housey songs that were entirely written on equipment he set up at his local Starbucks.

title: With Love
label: 4AD
description: Zomby's third album (and second for 4AD) is a two-disc set of short, nimble tracks loosely divided by attitude: "tough" on disc one, "contemplative" on disc two. With Love veers sharply from rhythmic duress to stoned calm, proving a reckless and inattentive immersive experience.

title: Carolina EP
label: Carpark
description: The latest EP by Teenie Lieberson's post-Here We Go Magic ensemble, TEEN, takes a pretty dramatic leap forward from their debut LP. The newly scrubbed-down production and bolder sonic palette allow these five songs to bloom impressively, in ways the shadowy corners of In Limbo couldn't.
