description: Depeche Mode's thirteenth album sounds like it could be a set of outtakes from 1993's Songs of Faith and Devotion. On Delta Machine, they don't even bother pretending technology has opened up any possibilities for recorded sound in the past 20 years.

title: Dragged Down a Dead End Path
label: Relapse
description: Like their peers in Early Graves and the now-deceased Gaza, Call of the Void traffic in a hybrid of hardcore, death metal, and crust; they're not so much interested in melody as they are with laying waste.

title: Culture of Pink
label: Hands in the Dark
description: The reggae-ish guitar, dub-like bass, and deep-end beats on Cankun's Culture of Pink have a lot in common with Sun Araw's gripping grooves. They're engulfed by a sweaty, tropical fog, though remain remarkably attention-grabbing thanks to Vincent Caylet's knack for arrangements.

title: Understated
label: AED
description: 2010's Losing Sleep was the former Orange Juice frontman's first release since suffering cerebral hemorrhages in 2005. Understated's predominant lyrical theme is one of triumphant return, and the album feels like a crucial step towards Collins rediscovering his muse.

title: Amygdala
label: Pampa
description: Stefan Kozalla's first original solo album in nine years, featuring contributions from Caribou, Matthew Dear, and more, is uncommonly engrossing for a techno record. Blessed with the carefree spirit of lounge music and Quiet Storm, and dressed up in tiedye, the music on Amygdala glows with an easy confidence.

title: Love & Devotion
label: Planet Mu
description: The debut release by Planet Mu boss Mike Paradinas and his wife Lara Rix-Martin is nothing like Paradinas' work as µ-ziq. Instead they synthesize warm, romantic pop a la Fleetwood Mac with somber, technological anxiety, and the inherently sad vocals of Gravenhurst's Nick Talbot.

title: Make Memories
label: Northern Spy
description: On the L.A. quartet's first album since 2009's Anti-Magic, Foot Village has loosened the thematic concepts of their past work, though the group's trademark anthemic chants, strident declarations, and cryptic slogans remain intact among abstract, expansive swelling textures.

title: 20 Jahre Kompakt / Kollektion 1
label: Kompakt
description: Once-seminal Cologne techno label Kompakt has, in part, sustained its 20-year existence through frequent compilation releases. The two-decade commemorative 20 Jahre Kompakt Kollektion isn't a greatest hits package, but a combination of defining songs and sentimental favorites.

title: Afraid of Heights
label: Mom & Pop
description: Afraid of Heights is the proper full-length follow-up to Wavves' 2010 breakthrough King of the Beach*.* Working with producer John Hill, it's Nathan Williams' best-sounding album to date, with touches of strings and background vocals from Jenny Lewis.

title: Meir
label: Roadrunner
description: The Norwegian band's second album, produced by Converge's Kurt Ballou and featuring cover art from Baroness' John Baizley, is their first for Warner subsidiary Roadrunner.

title: Off the Record
label: Bureau B
description: Off the Record is only the second album onetime Kraftwerk member Karl Bartos has made under his own name, and it's primarily based around music he recorded long ago, gathered from the vaults and given a 21st century gleam.

title: Miami
label: K7
description: On 2011's Mr. Machine, the Berlin group shifted their focus away from acoustic techno towards the concert hall, roping in a 10-piece orchestral ensemble. With the semi-conceptual Miami, they return to muscular sub-bass, booming kickdrums, and muscular, ominous arrangements.

title: Recover EP
label: Glassnote
description: The Glasgow trio's debut EP shows off Chvrches' penchant for exploring and embracing synth pop's artificial sunlight. The songs here are driven by themes of belief, devotion, and discovery, and imbued with an unabashed sense of wonder.

title: Comedown Machine
label: RCA
description: The Strokes' fifth album is more immediately appealing than their last two records as they sound like they’re genuinely trying here, and having fun. At times it feels like a mixtape the Strokes made for themselves: 11 songs, 11 different genre experiments.

title: Ensemble Pearl
label: Drag City
description: Given that Ensemble Pearl features members of Sunn O))), Boris, and Jesse Sykes & the Sweet Hereafter, it's a surprise that their six-song debut sounds so elegant and subdued. But it's a testament to the plasticity of the musicians who made it, rather than their potential combined power.

title: Lady
label: Truth & Soul
description: Lady is a new Transatlantic collaboration between Atlanta's Nicole Wray and London's Terri Walker, who both experienced minor success at the turn of the century. Truth and Soul's production draws liberally on Motown and MFSB disco, and lets the singers' personalities shine through.

title: Impossible Truth
label: Merge
description: The Nashville-based William Tyler's second album for solo guitar in three years offers a lovely, rangy meditation on open-string drones, though Tyler has an uncommon way of making tangles of picked notes ring out like the melody of a searching pop song.

title: Bloodsports
label: Suede Limited
description: On Suede's first post-reunion album, Bernard Butler remains absent, but his replacement, Richard Oakes, has an undeniably reinvigorating effect on frontman Brett Anderson. His lyrics strike the balance between decadence and elegance, and seek meaningful, one-on-one connections.

title: The New Life
label: Slumberland
description: The second album by Belfast's Girls Names sees them shed the morbid C86 bent of their debut, opting instead for a turn towards post-punk's dreamier, more spectral corners.

title: Life After Defo
label: Cooperative
description: London producer/singer-songwriter Daniel Woolhouse became known through a Mariah Carey tribute, and his icy debut LP focuses on glimmering organs, stuttering percussion, harp sounds, and digitized Bon Iver-style vocal swoops.

title: Entrench
label: Season of Mist
description: A belligerent shot of heavy metal and hardcore, math rock and no wave*, Entrench* is the Winnipeg band KEN mode's fifth album in 10 years, but the Matt Bayles-produced collection has the unbridled energy of a debut, down to frontman Jesse Matthewson's ferocious rants about idealism, middle-age, and religion.

title: The Invisible Way
label: Sub Pop
description: Jeff Tweedy produced the Duluth band's tenth studio album, placing an emphasis on the drama that distinguishes it from previous Low efforts. Alan Sparhawk and Mimi Parker sound like true equals here, as their writing, singing, and playing complement one another vividly.

title: Pretend To Be Brave
label: Magic Marker
description: Five albums into their career, Seattle's BOAT have carved out a niche in the crowded contemporary indie rock landscape by delivering tuneful power-pop with a sense of humor. Pretend to Be Brave, finds the group maintaining their finely honed sonic equilibrium while exploring new lyrical motifs.

title: The Stand-In
label: ATO
description: The Nashville singer-songwriter Caitlin Rose started out playing warehouse punk shows alongside bands like JEFF the Brotherhood. On her third album, featuring swooning pedal steel, twanging electric guitar, and ringing tube amps, she has some quibbles with the modern age.

title: Superpowerless
label: Morr
description: As bassist for Yo La Tengo since 1992, James McNew's songwriting eventually got absorbed into his main band's output. But his first two solo albums as Dump, reissued here, are modest, fuzzy records that lovingly represent the loser-happy indie pop rhetoric of his early 90s scene.

title: The Chronicles of Marnia
label: Kill Rock Stars
description: Marnie Stern's fourth album is an extension of the transition that began on her 2010 self-titled record toward a more controlled, subdued sound. Marnia is still aggressive, busy, and bright, but new drummer Kid Millions gives it a welcome sway, and the relative calm lets Stern's vulnerability shine through.

title: Sky Burial
label: Relapse
description: The second album by Inter Arma is a bleak picture of danger, apocalypse, despair, and dismay. But the Richmond, VA, band's energy and obvious enthusiasm for their unlikely alchemy of influences-- such as Zeppelin, Lightning Bolt, and Sleep-- make Sky Burial a truly exhilarating listen.

title: Water on Mars
label: Drag City
description: Purling Hiss started as the murky, fuzzed-out solo side-project of Mike Polizze, then the guitarist of Philadelphia free-form heavy rock outfit, Birds of Maya. War on Mars is the first record Polizze has done as part of a trio and also the first to be assembled in a professional studio.

title: The Patriarch
label: self-released
description: 25-year old NC rapper Deniro Farrar's voice falls somewhere between Bun B and former G-Unit great Young Buck. His second solo tape, featuring production from Ryan Hemsworth and Flosstradamas, finds him transcending the "blog-rap" tag.

title: Lines
label: Underwater Peoples
description: Four albums into his career, Julian Lynch continues to score deeper into his reputation for pristine arrangements, indecipherable lyrics, and swiftly curtailed genre explorations. Lines veers from dense folk to the lightly jazzy post-rock of Tortoise and the Sea and Cake.

title: The 20/20 Experience
label: RCA
description: On Justin Timberlake's first album in seven years, the pop superstar reunites with longtime producer/collaborator Timbaland for an album that seamlessly conflates the last 40 years of pop, soul, and R&B into a series of ambitious, long songs.

title: Via
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Via, the former Come singer specializes in thorny songs that unflinchingly address adult topics and problems, with the malleable backing of her guitar and band providing either momentary refuge or sympathetic cries of exasperation.

title: Ripely Pine
label: Ba Da Bing!
description: The debut studio album from singer-songwriter Aly Spaltro is filled with bloody, body-focused epics that call to mind Jeff Buckley, Okkervil River, Jack White, Helium, and the Dirty Three.

label: Rough Trade
description: Palma Violets are a young band who've already received ecstatic acclaim from the most excitable parts of the English music press. They sound like rock music probably entered their lives with the Arctic Monkeys, and they’re still thrilled by it.

title: Muchacho
label: Dead Oceans
description: On Muchacho, Matthew Houck's sixth full-length as Phosphorescent, he gathers together everything he's attempted to date-- beery, rollicking country-rock, haunted tribal hymnals, regret-soaked bar room heartbreak-- and fashions it into something close to a defining statement.

title: Known Flood
label: Sacrament Music
description: This urgent instrumental album welds the power of black metal, sludge metal, and grindcore to the structures and orders of post-rock and post-punk.

title: Sock it to Me
label: Hardly Art
description: The songs on the L.A.-via-Boston grunge-popper's first full-length are brazenly simple, but they have a shrugging, take-me-as-I-am charm that makes them feel like celebrations of their own limitations, recalling Beat Happening, the Ramones, and Blink-182 before they briefly grew up.

title: The False Alarms
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: L.A.'s fractured pop collective returns with an album that at its best builds on the modest success of early single "In Ruins". Elsewhere, the band experiments with coldwave and trance-inducing new wave.

title: Free Reign II
label: Domino
description: Clinic asked Oneohtrix Point Never's Daniel Lopatin to mix their 2012 album, Free Reign, only to shelve all but two of his submissions. On this complete album overhaul, the Liverpool band reinstate Lopatin's mixes and rejig the sequencing to astonishing effect.

title: The Plague of a Coming Age
label: Debemur Morti
description: The band led by Finland's M. Lehto continues to integrate nature-worshiping neo-folk with a harsher but still melodic mix of doom and black metal.

title: Invisible Life
label: Asthmatic Kitty
description: Over the past few years, Roberto Carlos Lange has gone from making softly warped, pastoral music with Spanish lyrics and Latin influences to more urbane pop with bi-lingual lyrics. A sultry, dreamy temperament always remains, and Invisible Life is Helado Negro's clearest record yet.

title: All My Relations
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Black Pus is the pop-inspired side project of Lightning Bolt's Brian Chippendale-- but it's only "pop" in comparison to his main gig's Jackson Pollock-style approach. All My Relations is the first Black Pus album to be recorded in a professional studio, and proves less blown-out, and more sing-songy than its predecessors.

title: Sleeper
label: Smalltown Supersound
description: Once a model who appeared on the covers of Vogue and Marie Claire, the singer's debut is the first music she's ever shared with the world, having written in private for years. Sleeper evokes the seedy prowl of Royal Trux and early Sonic Youth, and has a disaffected air.

title: The Deserters
label: Paper Bag
description: As half of Cat's Eyes with the Horrors' Faris Badwan, opera singer Rachel Zeffira sang smoochy girl-group songs through an orchestral, broken-radio haze. On her lavish solo debut, recorded in part at Abbey Road, she's a more spectral presence atop pillowy arrangements.

title: Adrian Younge Presents the Delfonics
label: Wax Poetics
description: Delfonics founding member and lead vocalist William Hart teams up with Adrian Younge for a surprisingly radical late-career record: Younge places Hart in a stylized version of the past that works as a tribute, deconstruction, and revamp of his band's once-vanguard Philly sound template.

title: Concrete Sustain
label: Seventh Rule
description: On their ambitious new album, the industrialized N.Y. metal band Batillus demonstrate their intention to shake loose the formulas of doom and stoner metal, breaking beyond the genre’s barriers, as well as their own.

title: Honky Tonk
label: Rounder
description: Jay Farrar has always stood up for the Little Guy in America, regular folks facing down some challenge. But Son Volt's latest, Honky Tonk, shows the Little Guy at leisure, channeling the midtempo stylings of musicians like Buck Owens and Merle Haggard.

title: Mala
label: Nonesuch
description: Having eased back significantly since 2009's ambitious What Will We Be, Banhart draws from pre-Beatles concepts of pop and rock on Mala, and writes from distinctly non-punk perspectives such as loving with levity, and aging with grace.

title: Toy Love
label: Flying Nun
description: They existed for less than two years, but the Chris Knox-fronted post-punk band Toy Love are immeasurably important to New Zealand music. Goner's Live at the Gluepot is a ripping double LP of recordings from their final shows. And, as part of its reissue program with Flying Nun, Captured Tracks has compiled two discs’ worth of singles and demos.

title: LISm
label: Bpitch Control
description: Adapted from a work Allien produced for a dance performance at Paris' Pompidou Centre in 2011, LIsm is a single track that clocks in at 45 minutes. It's her most fractured work to date, veering from abstraction into song-oriented forms through the clubby territory that made her name.

title: Between Places
label: Modular
description: This Norwegian pop collective has toured with Tame Impala, and has a sound that touches on the Beach Boys and Veckatimest-era Grizzly Bear. Their music exalts the transformative power of imagination.

title: Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre)
label: Mute
description: The Berlin producer Apparat's Krieg und Frieden (Music for Theatre) was adapted from a score for German director Sebastian Hartmann's 2012 theatrical production of Tolstoy’s War and Peace. The result is a delightful challenge to both fixity and expectations.

title: The Next Day
label: ISO
description: On several levels, David Bowie's 24th studio album is a cunning act of sleight of hand. From the "Heroes"-referencing cover on down, he hasn't only come to terms with his past, he's making his old material work for his new material.

title: Golden Grrrls
label: Slumberland
description: The Glaswegian indie pop trio's full-length debut follows a series of 7-inch and cassette-only releases that presented Golden Grrrls' modest, pared-down charms in appropriately modest, pared-down packages.

title: Deathfix
label: Dischord
description: The influence of Big Star and Deep Purple looms large over the first collaborative album by Fugazi's Brendan Canty and singer-songwriter/remixer Rich Morel, who met as members of Bob Mould's touring band.

title: Punk Authority EP
label: Software
description: The trajectory of noise musician Pete Swanson's solo recordings is one of increased corrosion. But on his new collection, Punk Authority, he pulls everything into a bigger, fuller, more expansive framework.

title: Misogyny Drop Dead EP
label: Human Level
description: Janine Rostron's EP for International Women's Day trades her usual impressionistic lyrics for overt statements about the necessary death of the patriarchy. Accordingly, she also adapts her vocal style, coming off like tUnE-yArDs' Merrill Garbus in reggae-influenced mode.

title: New Moon
label: Sacred Bones
description: The Men's follow-up to 2011’s Leave Home and last year’s Open Your Heart is a deeper and more mature record steeped in rock signifers; it shows the difference between respecting tradition and being boring, between quieting down and going soft, between being earnest and being sappy.

title: Ores & Minerals
label: Fat Cat
description: The follow-up to the London band's 2011 debut still sounds like many of the 90s American indie bands lovingly mimicked on that album, but comes off more as a winningly idiosyncratic hybrid of their own making than an enthusiastic photocopy.

title: Girl Talk
label: have 10p
description: The English singer-songwriter returns with her third album. Working outside the major label system (she used crowd-sourced funding to make Girl Talk), Nash seems to be rebelling against her fame, switching things up musically and adopting a more confrontational tone.

title: Social Experiment 003
label: No. 19 Music
description: The Canadian house duo's buffed up, high-gloss DJ mix uses minor key melodies and densely layered rhythmic patterns to get across their persistent themes of desire, obsession, self-disgust, and fear of abandonment.

title: Mowgli
label: Lefse
description: The young Chicago producer Nick Zanca records home-schooled electronic music as Mister Lies. His buzzed-about debut full-length is an act of auditory hypnosis egged on by repetition and lush textures.

title: Cerulean Salt
label: Don Giovanni
description: Last year's American Weekend, Katie Crutchfield's piercing debut as Waxahatchee, got passed around like a secret. Cerulean Salt, Crutchfield's second album, demonstrates newfound assurance, marking her as a new songwriting voice to reckon with.

title: Passages Into Deformity
label: Willowtip
description: Striking a balance between blinding technicality and hardcore-style breakdowns, the German death metal quartet Defeated Sanity's fourth album includes piano, freeform drums, and macabre noise interludes not usually associated with the genre.

title: Images Du Futur
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On their second record, Montreal's Suuns mix the mechanical pulse of krautrock, post-punk's fractured syntax, and unorthodox instrumental techniques in a manner that brings to mind Clinic.

title: In Dark Denim
label: Greedhead
description: The buzzed-out San Jose rapper, who says thrash metal and Biohazard were the music of his youth, has rapped over Suzanne Vega and Goldfrapp samples. On his debut for Das Racist member Heems' Greedhead label, his personality is ahead of his artistry.

title: A Love Surreal
label: eOne
description: A Love Surreal is only Bilal's third studio album in 12 years. Its jazzy, muted, idiosyncratic feel, and a lack of big guest names, makes it seem like the personal project of someone who has embraced the ability to make music away from commercial expectations.

title: Needs Continuum
label: No Pain in Pop
description: London-based Midwestener Karen Gwyer recorded her debut album on No Pain is Pop while pregnant with her first child. The result, which recalls Oneohtrix Point Never and Julianna Barwick, is a loosely finished collection that feels like entering a deeply private realm.

title: Hi Beams
label: Luaka Bop
description: In the handful of years they've been making music together, pop collagists George Langford and Tom Van Buskirk have never been afraid to push their luck. Doing away with their trademark samples, the slick-sounding, candy-colored Hi Beams is their first real studio record.

title: The Beast in Its Tracks
label: Pytheas
description: The Idaho singer-songwriter's last two albums were less about himself and more about America and all its weird history. The Beast in Its Tracks, however, chronicles Ritter's split from his wife in 2010, observed with a cool distance and scaled-back arrangements.

title: Laid Out EP
label: Friends of Friends
description: Shlohmo is part of a new wave of producers who make use of every musical ingredient available to them; they source samples and influences from any decade, genre, or style that they’re interested in. His latest EP makes brilliant use of vocal processing and has a guest spot from How to Dress Well.

title: Woman
label: Republic
description: Rhye is the project of singer/producer Mike Milosh and producer Robin Hannibal. Together, they make ethereal R&B focusing on world-tilting romantic experience, with gorgeous minimal production that leaves little space between the listener and the songs.

title: Askel Lähempänä Saatanaa
label: World Terror Committee
description: On their first album in five years, the legendary Finnish black metal band showcase their reverence for black metal's Second Wave as well as their deft utilization of melody within their jagged, apocalyptic compositions.

title: Hymnal
label: Kranky
description: As Benoît Pioulard, UK-via-Mich. multi-instrumentalist Thomas Meluch comes across as a doomed romantic slowly disappearing into his own reflection. His newest collection, which culminates in an imposing drone piece, was inspired by the religious iconography of Southern England and mainland Europe.

title: Untogether
label: Arbutus
description: Following their excellent, sun-kissed 2010 EP Blooming Summer, the Montreal electro pop duo of Alexander Cowan and Braids' Raphaelle Standell-Preston release a chillier full-length focused on themes of disconnect, alienation, and independence.

title: Trust EP
label: Ghostly
description: Three years on from Lucky Shiner and following his DJ-Kicks set, the new EP from Gold Panda finds him refining his approach and exploring familiar themes, mixing bell-like textures, slow-mo house, and foggy drone.

title: Wondrous Bughouse
label: Fat Possum
description: Youth Lagoon follows his heartfelt 2011 debut The Year of Hibernation with an album that is bigger, bolder, and more emotionally resonant, thanks to production from Ben Allen. Trevor Powers' project is firmly in the lineage of bands like Mercury Rev, Sparklehorse, and Modest Mouse.

title: Die zauberhafte Welt der Anderen
label: Kompakt
description: The title of the latest collaboration between brothers Wolfgang and Reinhard Voigt translates as "The Magical World of Others". It's less the straightforward collection of minimal techno you'd expect from them than an immersion into a strange universe that may or may not tell a story.

title: Selected Studies, Vol. 1
label: Bureau B
description: For Selected Studies, Vol. 1, the prolific krautrock elder statesman Hans-Joachim Roedelius collaborated with the bookish singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole by exchanging files online.

title: Cyclopean EP
label: Mute
description: The debut EP from Can co-founders Irmin Schmidt and Jaki Liebezeit and collaborators Jono Podmore and Burnt Friedman represents a phase of sonic mastery for these four innovators, rather than outright experimentation. Cyclopean is a crisp, seamless set.

title: Somewhere Else
label: Paper Bag
description: Somewhere Else isn't quite a departure from Sally Shapiro's last two albums, but in among the sequencers and identikit drums are instruments from a more muted palette: flute, saxophone, and beats that skitter rather than shimmer.

title: Chelsea Light Moving
label: Matador
description: With Sonic Youth drifting into an unofficial, maybe-permanent hiatus, Thurston Moore has started a louder, younger rock band featuring Samara Lubelski and members of Hush Arbors and Sunburned Hand of the Man. Their self-titled debut is the heaviest, most dissonant music Moore's put together in recent memory.

title: Privilege
label: Slender Means Society
description: On Parenthetical Girls' fourth album, the Portland indie-pop band's first since 2008, leader Zach Pennington plays the part of the amoral schoolboy fated to be caught in bed in a scandalous tryst with the headmistress or -master.

title: Homosapien
label: Felte
description: The Australian band explores a vast array of electronics-enhanced pop influences on their third album, their first to feature frontman Richard Pike's vocals on every song. It's just one aspect of an extensive band overhaul that's made them substantially more accessible.

title: Hello EP
label: Merok
description: The Montreal art pop artist's new EP makes good on Caila Thompson-Hannant's "bedroom paranoia" tag, bearing both a DIY pop aesthetic and a lyrical preoccupation with the anxieties of crushing, dating, and intimacy.

title: Les Revenants
label: Rock Action
description: Mogwai's soundtrack to the French drama of the same name rarely comes off overly dramatic or leading. While the musical structures are often simple, continually recasting the central motif with xylophone, piano, and guitar, they push individual sounds to disquieting levels.

title: Heliosphere
label: 50 Weapons
description: Following last year's They!Live collaboration with Doc Daneeka, Welsh producer Benjamin Damage moves into the harsher, straightline industrial realm of rave techno for his first solo collection.

title: An A.merican D.ream
label: Mexican Summer
description: Michael Gerner's surrealist trad-rock group returns for An A.merican D.ream, a record enamored with the thrilling possibilities and tired clichés of classic rock.

title: Outrun
label: Mercury
description: Kavinsky's "Nightcall" is almost as synonymous with Drive as Ryan Gosling. The French musician's new album isn't linked to a film, but centers around an automotive story of Kavinsky's creation, and replicates the soundtracks to 1980s driving video games with eerie accuracy.

title: Lesser Evil
label: Arbutus
description: The Canadian art-pop artist's debut album is as much a product of his time in Montreal and Toronto's DIY scenes as it is influenced by their predecessors in Brooklyn and Baltimore. But Lesser Evil is primarily rooted in Airick Woodhead's dystopian imagination.

title: Total Folklore
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Dan Friel's second solo album of blown-out, euphoric songs was made using cheap keyboards, chained pedals, field recordings, and knick-knacks. The precarious setup translates into punchy instrumentals instilled with raw energy, which doesn't stint on either side of the noise pop deal.

title: Optica
label: Merge
description: The Swedish band's fourth album is warm, expansive, and swimming in strings. The Shout Out Louds took their sweet time with Optica, and it shows.

title: Through the Window
label: Blackest Ever Black
description: Having taken a pleasurable detour toward grinding synth pop on his 2011 releases Bermuda Drain and Time's Arrow, with Through the Window, Dominick Fernow convincingly throws himself to the growling hounds of techno.

title: Anxiety
label: Mexican Summer
description: When Autre Ne Veut released his self-titled debut in 2010, his unwieldy, anonymous handle and approximations of 1980s and 90s R&B made him the epitome of a fringe concern. But Anxiety is a marvelous and moving second LP.

title: Velvet Changes
label: Carpark
description: Dog Bite is a dream pop project helmed by Washed Out sideman Phil Jones, who shares his other band's interest in billowy atmospheres and and gauzy layering.

title: The Underground Resistance
label: Peaceville
description: The Norwegian duo gave up on black metal a long time ago, turning instead to an open-ended interest in the metal they loved as kids: thrash and crust punk, high-flying British metal, and blustery hardcore. It's hard to imagine two middle-aged men having more fun than Darkthrone do on their propulsive sixteenth studio album.

title: Miracle Temple
label: Merge
description: The North Carolina band's second album marks their Merge debut, where Heather McEntire sings of a life yoked to the tides of a town ruled by college seasons. She's country to the core, a quality the rest of the band emphasize by knowing how to hang back.

title: AMOK
label: XL
description: Radiohead's Thom Yorke joins forces with Nigel Godrich, Flea, Joey Waronker, and David Byrne percussionist Mauro Refosco (the band he used to bring his solo album The Eraser to life) for the project's first studio album.

title: Rough Carpenters
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Rough Carpenters is the latest in an impressive string of full-lengths by the Appalachian acoustic quartet, and the swiftest, too. It's also the first to integrate fiddler/dancer Sally Anne Morgan, and sees the Pickers making strong vocal connections, an area where they once fell short.

title: Saal
label: Graveface
description: The Chicago native went to Bonn, Germany, to record Saal, and you can feel how the distance freed him up to experiment with form. Produced by avant-garde classical musician Tobias Vethake*,* the record sees David Cohn as spoken word poet and folk singer chronicling deep emotional despair.

title: Flume
label: Transgressive
description: The Australian beatmaker Flume mixes woozy Dilla-fied production, R&B-inspired bedside intimacy, and guest vocals on his promising debut.

title: The Marriage of True Minds
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Half the fun of any new Matmos album lies in its concept: Here, Drew Daniel and Martin Schmidt attempted to telepathically communicate their intentions for this record to a group of subjects, whose responses are woven into Marriage. The scientific approach resulted in an antic, lively record.

title: Jamie Lidell
label: Warp
description: Jamie Lidell faithfully recreates every Reagan baby's favorite rollerskate jams, trading in pop funk with some obvious forebears-- the Minneapolis sound of Prince and Jam/Lewis, Stevie Wonder circa In Square Circle, and red codpiece-era Cameo-- given a subtle IDM reworking.

title: The Best of the Howling Hex
label: Drag City
description: Naturally, The Best of the Howling Hex isn't a greatest hits collection; as if Neil Hagerty would ever be so straightforward. Instead, it's the Howling Hex's first album in six years to feature drums, which form the backbone for a record that endlessly repeats and refines its fusion of reggae, polka, acid rock, and cowpunk dust-ups.

title: House of Woo
label: Rvng Intl.
description: The second album from Washington D.C.'s Maxmillion Dunbar cherrypicks from fashionable pasts like house and early 90s R&B. But even at their most pounding, the rhythms of House of Woo are secondary to Andrew Field-Pickering's enchanting, vibrant way with sound.

title: DuFlocka Rant 2
label: 1017 Brick Squad
description: The appeal of DuFlocka Rant 2 can be compared to certain strains of extreme metal, where the gratification comes from surrendering to the onslaught. If Waka Flocka Flame has lowered the standards for writing in the rap world, he's also introduced a new level of catharsis.

title: Vexovoid
label: Profound Lore
description: The fourth album from Australian heavy metal abusers Portal is their shortest to date, but parsing it should take you the better part of this calendar year. Initially forceful and ultimately complex, Vexovoid redirects the image of death metal through a dervish funhouse.

title: For Professional Use Only
label: self-released
description: For Professional Use Only reflects AraabMuzik's current status: It's bigger and bolder than its predecessor, working as a souvenir for his fiercely loud sets while showing off his range as a producer.

title: Island Universe
label: Innovative Leisure
description: The California band's second album feeds off meandering Strange Days interludes, Sabbath sludge, and the loud and fast riffs of Feeding People's one-time Burger Records label mates Black Lips and Davila 666. The disparate strands are united by Jessie Jones' distinctive voice.

title: III
label: Woodsist
description: Eat Skull's first album in nearly four years almost sounds like the product of an entirely different band. The disembodied, screechy detritus floating amidst the sneakily catchy songs on the band's first two records has been pushed down low into a foreboding hum.

title: The Messenger
label: Sire
description: The Messenger is the big, bright, jangly guitar rock LP that Smiths fans would have killed for in 1994, full of fantastic guitar tones and cavernous choruses. But in 2013, it exists in its own, hermetically sealed context.

title: One Track Mind
label: Sacred Bones
description: As they enter their tenth year, New York's continually unpredictable Psychic Ills offer their most straightforward album to date: a coherent, if unwieldy, set of desert blues-bleached tracks, produced in part by the Howling Hex's Neil Hagerty.

title: no world
label: 4AD
description: The L.A. duo's debut album is very much in sync with the R&B slow jams made popular in recent months. But inc. doesn't aim to duplicate the vocal abilities or striking personalities of contemporaries Frank Ocean or Jessie Ware, opting instead for distinct, velveteen scene-setting.

title: Exai
label: Warp
description: Double LP Exai is Autechre's eleventh record, and the Manchester duo's longest by a margin of about 40 minutes. As ever, it shows Rob Brown and Sean Booth to be top-notch sonic magpies and brilliant technicians, but it fully justifies their reputation for being poor editors.

title: Miracle Mile
label: Polyvinyl
description: The usually chirpy Portland, Oregon synth poppers take a lyrically dark turn on their fourth album, where frontman Josh Hodges sings about his fear of death, restless nights, romantic tragedy, and emotional crisis.

title: Long Island
label: No Quarter
description: As frontman Paul Major approaches 60, Endless Boogie have earned the right to be comfortably stubborn. So Long Island operates strictly on the Brooklyn band's terms, where they log 80 minutes of psychedelia, garage, and scorched, Southern-fried stoner rock.

title: Clash the Truth
label: Captured Tracks
description: The New York City dream pop band's second album sees them introduce a darker, more socially aware edge, though it trades their former instrumental rigidity for amiable, mid-fi college rock jangle.

title: Songs for Imaginative People
label: Lucky Number
description: On Darwin Deez's followup to his self-titled 2010 debut, the whimsical singer-songwriter seems torn between celebrating and bemoaning commercial excess. The impression left is of a guy trying way too hard.

title: Companion
label: self-released
description: Companion is the new project of Pepi Ginsberg, who released a few appealingly lo-fi records under her own name. Here, she's unrecognizable as her former self. Full of glowing, magic-hour production and booming drums, Companion is a compellingly weird, personal pop record.

title: Lauschen
label: Bureau B
description: Hans-Joachim Roedelius (Zodiak Free Arts Lab, Harmonia, Cluster) epitomizes everything we associate with German experimental music over the last four decades. While Lauschen, his newest offering with Onnen Bock as Qluster, is head music, the body is not neglected.

title: Chalk Tape
label: Don Giovanni
description: The New Jersey trio's latest EP may be half as long as their 2012 full-length, Ugly, but it's twice as musically diverse, taking its predecessor's psychedelic influences into more sophisticated emotional terrain for some of the hookiest, most melodic songs Screaming Females have ever recorded.

title: Push the Sky Away
label: Bad Seed Ltd.
description: Push the Sky Away scans as the Bad Seeds' post-Grinderman comedown album, to be filed alongside their statelier turns. But where those usually find Cave in pensive, piano-man mode, the sound here is uncharacteristically weightless and eerily atmospheric.

title: Dreaming in Key
label: Atomnation
description: The Dutch producer's third album sees Pascal Terstappen combine springy tech house arpeggios, intrepid harmonic explorations, and tilted minimalist percussion with hefty ambient stuffing and a sparkly veneer of 90s IDM.

title: Spectral Park
label: Mexican Summer
description: Luke Donovan slathers tropicalia, drum machines, and organs over songs that run the gamut from proto-punk to synth pop. On his self-titled Spectral Park debut, the UK songwriter's phonographically enhanced one-man band's desperate words and frantic music make for a technicolored romantic frenzy.

title: Odd Furniture EP
label: Friends of Friends
description: Two years after the L.A. producer's Complex Housing, and a year after his trapped-up remix of Kanye's "Mercy", this five-song EP showcases Salva's delirious sense of rhythm, highlighting a trimmed-down take on his long-gestating style.

title: Cool Cocoon
label: Spintonic
description: With its color wheel-spinning palette, sticky, curlicued melodies, and poignant lyrical reflections, the Delaware band's fourth album is an occasionally breathtaking highwire walk between craft and genuine feeling that builds confidently on its predecessor.

title: All My Love in Half Light
label: self-released
description: California dreamer Melissa Ann Sweat's second album as Lady Lazarus has sturdier proportions and more sharply honed vocal melodies than her debut, Mantic. The palette is still largely solo voice and electric piano, but she's broken through her former oceans of reverb to project from the center of the frame.

title: No Elephants
label: Badman
description: No Elephants is Lisa Germano's ninth record, and her fourth since declaring that she was quitting the music business forever in 1998. The somewhat restricted palette explored here might scan as "pretty", but the lyrics are classic Germano: jarring, rough-hewn, and anguished.

title: Night Slugs: Allstars Volume 2
label: Night Slugs
description: Like its predecessor, the second volume of Night Slugs' label compilation ties together highlights from the roster's most visible and pivotal members including Girl Unit, Egyptrixx, Kingdom, and L-Vis 1990.

title: Confrontations
label: Not Not Fun
description: Matt Hill's fourth album of imaginary horror film soundtracks as Umberto subtly amps up the Italo disco influence palpable on last year's Night Has a Thousand Screams. It gives Confrontations a brilliant sheen that resembles a shift from fleapit to arthouse.

title: The Sundown Song
label: Brassland
description: Following 2010's The Creatures in the Garden of Lady Walton and its accompanying EPs, Clogs have released a moving three-song Padma Newsome solo recording intended as a coda to mark "an ending of what Clogs once were as well as a reaffirmation of what they continue to be."

title: Waiting for Something to Happen
label: Slumberland
description: Rather than offering a huge departure from their debut, the London quartet's second album is a showcase for subtle, wise tune-ups in the band's machinery. The most noticeable change is that Waiting for Something to Happen is a much warmer record than Veronica Falls.

title: Indigoism
label: Brainfeeder
description: The Brainfeeder-affiliated Brooklyn rap duo's debut mixtape has a druggy aesthetic. It's a work of art-damaged mysticism and Issa Dash and Ak's pyrotechnic wordplay, guided by the Entreproducers' broad, psychedelic production palette.

title: Holy Fire
label: Warner Bros.
description: There's an added element of showmanship to the Oxford band's third album that establishes it as a point of no return. It's easy to hear Holy Fire as a more muscular complement to Wild Beasts, though its overt commercial appeal aligns Foals with the Cure in stadium mode.

title: Vertikal
label: Indie
description: An heir to both Neurosis' sprawling post-metal cycles and their persistent development as an ensemble, Sweden's Cult of Luna is as much a posse as a band. Their sixth album unveils remarkably progressive doom, putting the surly form in uncomfortable positions and often finding a payload.

title: II
label: Melodic
description: On their sophomore album, featuring guest vocals from Annie, the self-proclaimed Finnish "anti-band" has taken things to a new level, infusing their sound with free jazz, drone, noise, pop, and rock.

title: No Beginning No End
label: Blue Note
description: New York-via-Minneapolis singer José James, who has collaborated with Flying Lotus, was once comfortable being the oddball talent of the contemporary jazz scene; with his latest, he's stripped his music down and zeroed in on vibe.

title: A Long Way to Fall
label: Domino
description: The producer's latest finds him leaving his laptop shoegaze approach behind and ditching vocals in favor of airy mid-tempo instrumentals.

title: Honeys
label: Sub Pop
description: On the Philly-via-Allentown band's fourth LP, Pissed Jeans trust in the power of honesty in Matt Korvette's lyrics while dropping the musical defense mechanisms that may once have kept listeners at a distance. It's headbanging music that allows you to nod feverishly in agreement.

title: Got Me So EP
label: Rinse
description: Over a steady stream of singles and EPs, Rupert Taylor has mingled Chicago house, UK garage, and bass music, usually in craftier ways than his peers. On his new three-song EP, his sound has hardened into something neon and machine-smooth.

title: Us Alone
label: Arts & Crafts
description: The Canadian singer-songwriter's seventh album in 17 years is his first for Arts & Crafts, home to Broken Social Scene and all of its many offshoots. Despite the new label, Hayden hasn't beefed up his sound on Us Alone. Instead, he's pared down even more.

title: News From Nowhere
label: Warp
description: On their second full length, the London electronic trio continue shapeshifting from a forward-facing Kode9/Hyperdub-approved production crew to pillowy dreampop dudes with genuinely charming and well crafted songs at their disposal.

title: Rumours
label: Rhino
description: Upon its release in 1977, Rumours, now reissued as a 4xCD/DVD/LP box set featuring live recordings, alternate mixes, and studio outtakes, became the fastest selling LP of all time, moving 800,000 copies per week at its height. Its success made Fleetwood Mac a cultural phenomenon and also set a template for pop with a gleaming surface that has something complicated, desperate, and dark resonating underneath.

title: LAST
label: Rad
description: As Little Wings, Kyle Field has made a practice out of hiding out from the world while continuing to try and understand it. There's a sepia flatness to his newest collection: Field might be singing about death, life, or sitting around his house, but it's all going to touch on the same idea that the quietest moments are also the most transcendent ones.

title: Cabinet of Curiosities
label: Trouble in Mind
description: With his head stuck in classic albums of 1960s studio wizards, and with very few collaborators, the 24-year-old Dutch multi-instrumentalist Jacco Gardner spent the past couple years creating the psychedelic pop universe of his debut.

title: The Jazz Age
label: BMG
description: Reworking his past material as jazz instrumentals, Bryan Ferry's The Jazz Age is a self-consciously 1920s collection, openly meant to evoke Louis Armstrong, early Count Basie, and the initial mass popularization of the form.

title: Pedestrian Verse
label: Canvasback / Atlantic
description: The Scottish band's fourth album avoids the escapist tendencies of their previous records to confront social and emotional turmoil with startling bite. And production from Leo Abrahams, a longtime Brian Eno collaborator, breaks through the sluggishness that had marked their recent releases.

title: Sugarglider
label: Mint
description: The Edmonton musician formerly known as Sugarglider named his pastel-colored debut after that discarded moniker. The collection, one continuous, mirrorball-powered jam, is full of gummy basslines, sax hooks, and spaced-out disco nods*.*

title: Wraetlic
label: Convex Industries
description: Wraetlic is the new alias of Alex Menzies, or Alex Smoke, the Scottish producer whose albums have long toed the line between the dancefloor and the psychiatrist's couch. On this self-titled collection, he dispenses with any notion of body music in favor of stirring, sour tracks.

title: Country Sleep
label: Dead Oceans
description: The 23-year old singer-songwriter Winston Yellen, blessed with jump-out-of-the-gym vocal athleticism, recorded Night Beds' debut in a Nashville house once owned by Johnny Cash. It's a sad, beautiful collection showcasing a young talent loved and lost beyond his years.

title: Stones Throw & Leaving Records: Dual Form
label: Stones Throw
description: Brainfeeder beat wizard Matthewdavid and visual artist Jesselisa Moretti's oddball label Leaving Records partnered with Stones Throw to release this eclectic 19-track compilation featuring work from Julia Holter, Odd Nosdam, Sun Araw, Dntel, Dem Hunger, the Cyclist, and others.

title: 100 Records Vol. 3
label: Polyvinyl
description: Sonny Smith's final installment in his 100 Records project, in which he inhabits a universe of fictional musicians, has the feel of a compilation sourced by grabbing random 45s from a bargain bin. But importantly, he always sounds decidedly like himself.

title: Artist Proof
label: Drag City
description: Drag City has a decent repuation for rescuing private press albums of yore from absolute obscurity. Unearthing Darrow's 1972 debut, Artist Proof, may be their greatest success yet: It's close to the platonic ideal of the California country rock that was being produced at the time.

title: Out of View
label: Marshall Teller
description: The London nostalgists' debut album appropriates the signature fuzzed-out rock sound of indie's golden years in much the same way as Best Coast and Real Estate recontextualized 1960s guitar pop. Strong songwriting tempers its potentially objectionable naivety.

title: Silver Cloud EP
label: Werk Discs
description: Darren Cunningham's new EP is a return of sorts to more beat-oriented material following the pastoral landscapes of R.I.P. It contains his longest song to date, and mines similar dungeon house territory to Andy Stott's recent work.

title: II
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The Portland/New Zealand band's second album is equal parts occasionally remarkable and frustrating, split between incredible pop songs and turgid guitar noodling with very little middle ground.

title: Baphometic Chaosium
label: Metal Blade
description: Although the L.A. black metal band are often hamstrung by their position on a major indie and by their slightly dubious touring history, they peddle a twisted black metal alloy as savage and hate-fueled as that of any underground darling. Baphometic Chaosium is alienating and vile-- that's a good thing.

title: In Guards We Trust
label: Black Bell
description: Fronted by Richie Follin, brother of Cults' Madeleine, Guards' debut LP has been a long time in the making. While there are plenty of nods to the past in its zippy, palm-muted riffs and crate-digging genre touches, the heavy low-end production brings it roundly into the present day.

title: Oddfellows
label: Ipecac
description: After a nearly six-year absence, Tomahawk-- Jesus Lizard guitarist Duane Denison, Helmet/Battles drummer John Stanier, Fantomas/Melvins bassist Trevor Dunn, and Mike Patton-- have returned with their fourth LP. Recorded with Black Keys producer Collin Dupuis, Oddfellows has been touted as the band's most straightforward release to date.

title: We the Common
artist: Thao & the Get Down Stay Down
label: Ribbon Music
description: Conscious of having spent her 20s on tour, Thao Nguyen settled in San Francisco and got involved in the community in pursuit of so-called real life experience. Accordingly, We the Common teases out the tension between life and art, the individual and the community, security and restlessness.

title: Regions of Light and Sound of God
label: ATO
description: If My Morning Jacket's albums have mostly come together like a revival meeting-- a group playing live, working together to create something larger than its members-- frontman Jim James' first solo album, Regions of Light and Sound of God, emerges from something closer to meditation.

title: Cold War
label: Underwater Peoples
description: La Big Vic's 2011 debut, Actually, translated leftfield influences from new age to dub into an engaging, appealing collection. Its follow-up blows their approach widescreen, with a reinvigorated focus on beats, and solid, guiding song structures.

title: Slime Flu 3
label: self-released
description: On the final part of the Slime trilogy, Harlem rapper Vado makes his most definitive showing to date, proving that he deserves to be a fixture in the contemporary New York rap conversation.

title: No Thrills
label: Double Denim
description: London's Joe Flory has escaped the hungry major label world of his past as Primary 1 to make a record on his own terms as Amateur Best. No Thrills is homemade, boldly rendered pop that crafts a human world from cartoon sonics, and knows the power of restraint.

title: The Man Who Died in His Boat
label: Kranky
description: Liz Harris' newest collection of charred ambiance is a companion to 2008's Dragging a Dead Deer Up a Hill recorded during the same period. The gorgeous and haunting The Man Who Died in His Boat shares many of that earlier record's characteristics and essential appeal.

title: Elliphant EP
label: A Bigger Splash
description: Swedish MC/producer Elinor Olovsdotter is part of the same production family as Icona Pop. But her debut EP plays against the sheen of wry, robotic Scandinavian pop by drawing on a number of elements of dancehall culture.

title: Adam Green & Binki Shapiro
label: Rounder
description: The former Moldy Peach teams up with the singer of Little Joy for a full length that mines the legacies left by Lee and Nancy, Richard and Linda, and Gram and Emmylou, but transcends merely accurate pastiche by imbuing the collection with intelligence and wryness.

title: Somewhere Else
label: 4AD
description: The evocative debut from Copenhagen's Søren Løkke Juul dissolves the boundaries between folk, piano balladry, arena rock, and post-rock, resulting in something unclassifiable and wholly his.

title: The House at Sea
label: Merge
description: The second album by the Clientele's Alasdair MacLean and Pipas' Lupe Nunez-Fernandez is a significant improvement on their debut, Street of the Love of Days. The transformation can largely be chalked up to their heightened dedication to the project, making for a more defined collection.

title: Tastes the Broom
label: Mexican Summer
description: Since 2009, Brattleboro, Vt.'s Happy Jawbone Family Band have released hundreds of songs exploring their lo-fi, disturbed take on whimsy via tiny homegrown labels. Mexican Summer will release their next record, for which this retrospective compilation acts as a primer.

title: Down by the Racetrack EP
label: Revolver
description: For Guided by Voices, reuniting wasn't a case of making a quick buck before disappearing again. They're back for the long haul, as proven by last year's trilogy of albums, which they now follow with a typically bizarre, extemporaneous EP-- ahead of another album, naturally.

title: Broken English: Deluxe Edition
label: Island
description: Released in 1979 following periods of homelessness, heroin addiction, and scandal, Marianne Faithfull's opus recovered her from exile and captured a generation's disillusioned comedown. As it receives the Deluxe treatment, Broken English's statement on the simple audacity of survival is still raw enough to make you squirm.

title: Send a Prayer EP
label: Rush Hour
description: Send a Prayer's four tracks suggest that German producer Danilo Plessow has little intention of discarding the warm, crackly thump that's defined his sound, but that doesn't mean he's not interested in toying with that sound's confines.

title: La Busta Gialla
label: Clenchedwrench
description: A few days after Minutemen/fIREHOSE legend Mike Watt formed a group with Italian musicians Stefano Pilia and Andrea Belfi, the trio headed off on tour. Their debut is a rickety listen, teetering between tautly composed prog and loosely formed grooves.

title: General Dome
label: Brassland
description: On their second full-length, the Hudson duo continue to skate their own electric rail between prog and post-punk. A great sense of speed and combustion thrums through the music, which is offset by Arone Dyer's engaging, limber vocal performance.

title: The Flower Lane
label: Domino
description: Matt Mondanile's first two Ducktails LPs were cozy, blithely executed indie rock comfort food that occasionally coalesced into semi-structured songs. But with New Jersey power-poppers Big Troubles as his backing band and a handful of choice guests, The Flower Lane is a more sumptuous, agile effort.

title: Pillowfight
label: Bulk
description: Over a career spanning two decades, Dan "the Automator" Nakamura's influence as a producer has been felt all the way up to the charts. His new project, Pillowfight, is a collaboration with Emily Wells that aims for Nancy Sinatra, but comes off more Lana Del Rey.

title: Eight
label: Merge
description: If you followed indie rock with any tenacity in the early 2000s, Radar Bros. was the kind of band that capably hung around the periphery. Their latest record, released as Radar Brothers, is a charming anachronism that functions better as a nostalgic device than any proper case for relevancy.

title: Heartthrob
label: Warner Bros.
description: The title of Tegan and Sara's seventh album is a reference to how we relate to the objects of our affection as teenagers. Produced by Greg Kurstin (P!nk, Kelly Clarkson, Lily Allen), the concise, radio-friendly collection finds them exploring a populist pop bent.

title: Hummingbird
label: Frenchkiss
description: On the L.A. band's debut, their influences floated incredibly close to the surface. But Hummingbird is a record of lateral growth, a clear move towards the band establishing their own footing among their contemporaries.

title: Repeat
label: End of Time
description: Hardly Art offshoot End of Time Records' inaugural release is by Wimps, a Seattle trio featuring members of the Intelligence, Meth Teeth, and Partman Parthorse, who write bright, bubbly punk hooks about how the world is a dismal place.

title: Home
label: Innovative Leisure
description: Low End Theory associate Nosaj Thing's second album serves as a kind of twilight to its predecessor Drift's midnight, elaborating on Jason Chung's icy sound with occasional hints of pop clarity. Guests include Toro Y Moi and Kazu Makino of Blonde Redhead.

title: FIDLAR
label: Mom & Pop
description: The L.A. skate-punk band's debut full-length is full of snotty songs about cheap beer, cheap cocaine, cheap weed, and "shitty pills." They're not reinventing the wheel, but FIDLAR have their references down.

title: Hardcourage
label: Ninja Tune
description: Drew Lustman has made a career out of inhabiting ambivalence, flitting between house and garage, dub and techno, frequently led by his experimental jazz background. But on Hardcourage, he's loosened his thrall to introspection in favor of a newfound openness, and the results are great fun.

title: Candela
label: Fat Cat
description: Mice Parade's latest once again surveys world music through a bracing indie pop filter. Across 10 tracks, Adam Pierce and a half-dozen guests toy with Afropop and Afrobeat, flamenco guitar and singing, samba and gamelan, Appalachian folk rearrangements and icy European electronic ambience.

title: Torres
label: self-released
description: Mackenzie Scott's voice conveys raw, urgent desperation. Veering between rangy indie rock and hushed folk, the 22-year old Nashville vocalist and guitarist's self-recorded debut conjures the hypnotic hurt of the earliest, best Songs:Ohia or Cat Power.

title: Goldenheart
label: self-released
description: On her second studio album, Dawn Richard proves her mettle as a fiercely independent force in a world dominated by name-dropping and endless collaborations. Goldenheart was largely produced by just one guy, Druski, leaving Richard's epic portrayal of love as war to flourish.

title: Christopher
label: Sub Pop
description: On the Ruby Suns' fourth album, they dive headlong into splashy chart pop before heading back to the surface just as quickly. The poppy moments are effusive and invigorated, although Christopher takes a sobering turn back to reality halfway through.

title: Illmatic
label: Get on Down
description: The 1994 hip-hop landmark is reissued in a box set with vinyl, a gold CD, an ersatz cherry wood case, and a 48-page book. Almost 20 years later, it remains a sterling example of how great rap can be.

title: Wash the Sins Not Only the Face
label: Matador
description: Where earlier releases suggested goth-tinged pop similar to Zola Jesus and Austra, Esben and the Witch's latest experiments offer spikier textures and more rhythmic variation.

title: Yeah Right
label: Kanine
description: The Philadelphia duo formerly known as Reading Rainbow expand to a four-piece for their first record as Bleeding Rainbow, discarding their old, cutesy image for a darker, dreamier stance.

title: True Hallucinations
label: Other Music
description: The new release from Other Music's record label isn't what you'd expect from the expertly obscurist shop. Instead, True Hallucinations is a record of finely executed dream pop that packs a considerable amount of dynamic variation into a limited range.

title: Sometimes Good Weather Follows Bad People
label: Jealous Butcher
description: This vinyl-only reissue gathers Califone's two self-titled EPs that were collected on a CD under this name in 2002, but adds a cache of unreleased Red Red Meat material to attract completists.

title: We Are the 21st Century Ambassadors of Peace & Magic
label: Jagjaguwar
description: The L.A. duo's second album seems to be reporting from three simultaneous decades of rock history. But having a great record collection and having some idea what to do with it are two different things, and on W**e Are The Ambassadors Foxygen have internalized enough of the music they love to start toying with it.

title: The Choir, the Army
label: Under the Spire
description: From 2010's Llanos to 2011's Sufferers and Merciless, Mike Shiflet has found new possibilities in his abstract, drone-indebted sound by diving deeper into it. His sense of guidance is palpable, turning The Choir, the Army into a kind of wordless story.

title: Oak Island
label: Secretly Canadian
description: On his second album as Nightlands, the War on Drugs' Dave Hartley has made a crush mixtape for the Uncanny Valley; exploring a similar palette to that of Destroyer's Kaputt, but rendered with an intentionally android effect.

title: Beta Love
label: Barsuk
description: For their third album, Ra Ra Riot enlisted producer Dennis Herring (Modest Mouse, Elvis Costello) and incorporated more keyboards and synthesizers to help them move away from the bittersweet violin and cello they felt had come to pigeonhole them since their first release in 2006.

title: Centralia
label: Thrill Jockey
description: On Centralia, the Brooklyn electro-acoustic duo Mountains have finally landed in a place as vast and awe-inspiring as the landforms they're named after. This is music for wide open spaces, full of reach and depth.

title: Anything In Return
label: Carpark
description: Serving as a synopsis of everywhere he's taken Toro Y Moi to date, Chaz Bundick's third full-length is also the longest and loudest of his releases. Here's silky R&B, roller-rink pop, bubblegum funk, and tasteful chillout music, all unified by a voice that's grown more confident with time.

title: Reasons to Live
label: Don Giovanni
description: The Brooklyn punk-rock duo Hilly Eye features onetime Titus Andronicus member Amy Klein. On their full-length debut, songs are built on simple, opaque lines that are transformed into stinging slogans.

title: Arc
label: RCA
description: On the Manchester art-rock band's second album, the flat-out ridiculousness of their debut is replaced with a mixture of concise, moving, often funny pop singles, mid-paced laments, and roiling tirades.

title: Brokeback and the Black Rock
label: Thrill Jockey
description: For Tortoise and Eleventh Dream Day member Douglas McCombs' first Brokeback album since 2003, he's assembled a simple guitar-bass-drums lineup as if he's reached a point of no return for the post-rock template he had a hand in defining.

title: Almanac
label: Captured Tracks
description: On their sophomore album, the crestfallen Brooklyn duo deepen their blend of mariachi, spaghetti western soundtracks, and 90s sad-rock.

title: La Costa Perdida
description: Camper Van Beethoven's first record in eight years is more approachable than its predecessor, tying together the chopped-genre sundaes of David Lowery's alma mater with a thread of sunbaked Northern Californian pleasantries. It's delightful if not all that memorable.

title: Lost Sirens
label: Rhino
description: As the title implies, the latest New Order release contains extras from the band's Waiting for the Sirens Call era-- their last sessions with Peter Hook. Following tussles over mixes and copyright, they release the leftovers, a remix, and "Hellbent", from 2011's Joy Division/New Order singles cash-in, Total.

title: Out of Touch In The Wild
label: Memphis Industries
description: On their third album, the Manchester band's brainy take on art-pop includes glassy, Reichian xylophone and marimba, Talk Talk-y guitar ticks, and choppy Stravinsky-inspired string sections.

title: Millionaire Dreamzzz
label: self-released
description: Following his bounce-reviving 2011 mixtape Swagga Fresh Freddie, Millionaire Dreamzzz displays the New Orleans producer-turned-rapper coming into his own as an MC. His beats are still bonkers, but now they're in service of something greater than just sounding wild.

title: Love Sign
label: Free People
description: The 70s-nodding Philadelphia pop-rock band's second album raises the question: When a record that so desperately wants to be universally loved ends up being divisive, is it doing something wrong?

title: California X
label: Don Giovanni
description: This Amherst, MA power-trio's self-titled debut is filled with molasses-thick grunge and burly classic rock that isn't far-off from the mess Dinosaur Jr. have been kicking up off-and-on for 30 years. It's the kind of frantic, desperate record that hits you squarely in the gut.

title: Coming Out of the Fog
label: Thrill Jockey
description: Over the years, Arbouretum's struggled to strike a compromise between spirit-world imagery and Americana-tinged bar-rock. On the Baltimore band's fifth album, their eerier inclinations are back in alignment with their amplifiers.

title: Mystical Weapons
label: Chimera
description: Mystical Weapons is the collaboration between Deerhoof drummer Greg Saunier and Sean Lennon. Their debut collection's a 36-minute set of proggy instrumental improvisations.

title: Lysandre
label: Fat Possum
description: The former Girls frontman steps out with his first solo LP, a sort of prog-folk concept album based on very specific details of a particular moment in Owens' life with instrumentation heavy on sax and flutes.

title: Mandatory Brunch Meetings
label: Mishka
description: The Queens rapper's new mixtape features beats by Mike Finito, Alchemist, and Harry Fraud and guest spots from Action Bronson and Heems, among others. But when the group falls away, and Meyhem Lauren is forced to make a track stand on its own, what happens?

title: {Awayland}
label: Domino
description: Fronted by the Irish troubadeur Conor O'Brien, Villagers start with humble folk and build outward with daunting orchestral arrangements and subtle electronics. The band's second album is filled with big ideas and sentiments.

title: In Focus?
label: Polyvinyl
description: Shugo Tokumaru creates toy-box indie pop with his vast collection of noise makers and a computer. He's been doing this for a while now, with varying degrees of success, but on his fifth album it all comes together in a beautifully sharp series of audio bursts.

title: Light Up Gold
label: What's Your Rupture?
description: Parquet Courts are slackers in an almost classical sense, conjuring up just about every post-collegiate, pre-responsibility tendency you can think of. Their music ably mixes skittish post-punk and bedhead-riddled indie rock, a knot of Silkworm-inspired guitar tangles and insistent Wire tempos.

title: Fade
label: Matador
description: Deep into their career, Yo La Tengo's sense of craft is intact. Fade, at a tight 10 songs and 46 minutes, is the band's shortest album since 1990's Fakebook; it may tread over some familiar turf, but the relaxed pacing and pleasing melodies belie just how much action is really going on beneath the serene surfaces.

title: Opus 2
label: Kranky
description: Opus 2 was recorded over a Pacific Northwest winter, during a period where Californian musician Tim Gray was working night shifts providing technical support for hospital operating theaters. The remove from reality burns through this freezing, inward collection.

title: Selling My Soul
label: Nature Sounds
description: With plenty of distended soul samples, slivers of dialogue, and Masta Killa's cautious, GZA-mentored flow, the Wu-Tang MC's long-delayed third solo album has all the hallmarks of a proper Wu-Tang LP.

title: Rifts
label: Mexican Summer
description: This expanded and re-ordered set collects three albums of early material from Daniel Lopatin's synth-based project. He successfully liberates synth sounds from their conventional trappings, placing them in less familiar contexts and coaxing you to hear them in new ways.

title: The Island Come True
label: Melodic
description: On his fourth and best L. Pierre release, the onetime Arab Strap mouthpiece Aidan Moffat uses crackling piano suites, field recordings, found loops, and swelling bits of dusty classical pieces to create a dark, moving listening experience.

title: Out of It and Into It
label: ATP
description: The New York neo-folk band perform music at coffeehouse volume, but their core inspiration owes more to Tom Verlaine than Alan Lomax. The duo's third album, which arrived last March in the UK, is now seeing US release, possibly timed to their upcoming tour supporting Jeff Mangum.

title: The Ballasted Orchestra
label: Kranky
description: In the 1990s, Stars of the Lid's Adam Wiltze and Brian McBride were making druggy and internally-focused drone music. On the East Austin, Tex., duo's sophomore album, reissued here on remastered vinyl, they did away with voices and followed their drones to a place where words have no meaning.

title: Container Ships
label: Brutal Panda
description: The Bay Area noise-rock quartet's sophomore album shares similarities with the kind of "post-metal" that has often led to critical crossover success, but when they're at their best, Kowloon Walled City don't engage in the indulgences of the bigger names in that field.

title: Loyal
label: Ghostly
description: Of all Jakub Alexander's pursuits and side projects, his work as "low level" ambient act Heathered Pearls is designed to give him a break from his personal anxieties. While tension clearly fed into Loyal, it doesn't give much back out, dealing instead in gentle mood shifts that crystallize over the course of the record.

title: Elements of Light
artist: Pantha Du Prince & The Bell Laboratory
label: Rough Trade
description: Originally conceived as a performance for 2011's Øya festival in Oslo, the recording of Elements of Light is an impressive example of how versatile the lowly bell can be, and offers familiar beats and bass swells from Hendrik Weber's world shot through with giddy-making surprises.

title: Bivouac
label: Blackball
description: The 1992 sophomore album from the Bay Area punk trio found them transitioning from the poppier sound of 1990's Unfun to something darker, grittier, more experimental, and even smarter. This remastered 20th Anniversary reissues appends a couple of bonus tracks to Jawbreaker's ragged call to arms.

title: Everything Touching
label: Big Scary Monsters
description: Known for their ferocious live show, the Brighton-based post-rock band's long-time-coming debut is equal parts meditative and cathartic.

title: Blood Oaths of the New Blues
label: Fire
description: During the last decade, James Jackson Toth has used the Wooden Wand handle and variations on it to release a mountain of barely compatible material. His proper debut for British vanguard Fire Records captures the best essences of this career in 41 seamless minutes.

title: Trouble Man: Heavy Is the Head
label: Atlantic
description: T.I.'s scattershot 70-minute eighth album features guest spots from A$AP Rocky, R. Kelly, André 3000, Pink, Lil Wayne, Cee Lo Green, Meek Mill, and others.

title: Persuasive Barrier
label: Spectrum Spools
description: As a member of other people's bands, Robert Beatty specializes in aggressive, speaker-splitting noise-- which also stretched to his work as an artist of album sleeves. But his debut release as Three Legged Race, a chilly electronic project, is all about restraint, echo, distance, and nuance.

title: Billow Observatory
label: Felte
description: The debut album from Manual's Jonas Munk and Jason Kolb of Auburn Lull was created largely with analog sources and electric guitars, recorded live and then processed into glowing smears, periodic spasms of rhythm, filaments of texture. The effect forms a reflection of the sky's expanse.

title: L.A.M.F.: Definitive Edition
label: Jungle
description: The crucial New York punk document of Johnny Thunders' band has been expanded to a 4-CD box set, complete with multiple mixes and rare demos.

title: Silent Congas
label: DFA
description: Greek producer Larry Gus' work can serve as an index of where sample-based music is right now: repetitive, simply structured grooves that draw a little on a lot of genres. Silent Congas doesn't so much envision a new world as recreates an old one that hardly feels like it existed in the first place.

title: Tropical Psychedelics
label: Emotional Response
description: Until now, L.A.'s Eddie Ruscha Jr.-- the progeny of the famed pop artist-- has been reticent about letting the bedroom-woven electronica he makes as Secret Circuit see the light. But the analog components, modular synths, and dusty drum machines of Tropical Psychedelics seems to hint at breakout tendencies.

title: Vanquish in Vengeance
label: Listenable
description: Incantation helped to define the sound of death metal and their ninth album doesn't stray far from the template. The macabre, lumbering grooves and aggressive blasts remain intact, but slightly brighter production gives the songs a different tint.

title: Drilluminati
label: Unknown
description: The 24-year-old Chicago rapper is both a veteran of his hometown scene and an up-and-comer associated with the surging drill sound. The Drilluminati mixtape serves as a solid placeholder while he preps his major label debut.

title: Whiteout EP
label: Our Dawn
description: While we wait for the release of her proper debut album, the R&B singer offers up another tantalizing EP. Here she's in full-on mystic mode, with four new songs that each offer a different variation on a fairly precise idea of ethereal electronic pop.

title: Bodily Functions
label: Accidental
description: The reissue of Matthew Herbert's landmark 2001 album Bodily Functions gathers period remixes and a few new versions in one package. But the real star is the album itself, which is arguably his finest.

title: The Paranormal Soul
label: Clone
description: The prolific Dutch producer follows 2011's The Teac Life with a record that seamlessly blends pronounced dance paradigms, from house to techno and electro.

title: Nayim From The Halfway Line
label: Domino
description: The Hot Chip singer and multi-instrumentalist's second solo collection, the first since 2008, showcases a familiarly bookish approach to clubland and a further progression of his work away from his main band.

title: Loosies
label: Fool's Gold
description: The latest Fool's Gold compilation scrapes up quality material from buzzed-about artists like Danny Brown and AraabMuzik, while also letting a handful of unknowns grab at the spotlight.

title: Taco Leg
label: Fan Death
description: Ambling through 12 songs in just under 20 minutes, the Perth, Australia post-punk primitivists' self-titled debut is a document of deep and devoted slacker-ism.

title: Living With Ghosts
label: Hotflush
description: On his debut LP, London techno producer James Shaw favors an unforgiving all-rhythm-everything approach. Industrial in the most literal sense, it's big music meant for big spaces.

title: Orbits
label: Civil Music
description: The eclectic dubstep producer's third full-length manages to draw his diverse influences together into a streamlined signature sound. In almost every track, there's a rhythmic structural curveball that upends the typical expectations of buildups and breakdowns.

title: Tuna Melt EP
label: Fool's Gold
description: The Fool's Gold cofounder, and onetime Kanye West tour DJ, knows what qualities a song needs to move a crowd. This new four-song EP is cleary intended to put that knowledge to work.

title: Finally Rich
label: Interscope
description: Chief Keef's major label debut stays true to the mixtapes that got him noticed, and proves that the young Chicago rapper has more potential than his detractors might have hoped.

title: Longing
label: Profound Lore
description: Featuring Samothrace bassist Dylan Desmond, the Seattle metal duo's spacious, somber debut is defined by inescapable haunting and loss, but they have a knack for turning maudlin doom into perverted praise music.

title: O.N.I.F.C.
label: Atlantic
description: Wiz Khalifa smokes weed by the acre, but his career to date has been driven by his own shrewd vision for himself. O.N.I.F.C., his second major label album, is the first sign that this unwavering focus may be getting swallowed up by the haze.

title: The Narcissist II
label: Hippos in Tanks
description: The Hype Williams producer's first album as a solo artist is a remastered version of a free, 30-minute mixtape he originally released in February. It's the latest reminder that he thinks about pop music very, very differently than you do.

title: Wish
label: Volar
description: Window Twins are a collaboration between Fresh & Onlys' Tim Cohen and Jon Bernson of the deconstructivist electro-pop group Exray's. Their second album explores the scuzzy, sinister, and lo-fi fringes of jazzy R&B and ramshackle folk.

title: Jesus Piece
label: Interscope
description: Game's business is making you cringe for him, and on his fifth studio album, a collection featuring spots from 2Chainz, Rick Ross, Meek Mill, Lil Wayne (twice), Future, Young Jeezy, Chris Brown, Common, Pusha T, Jamie Foxx, J. Cole, Kendrick Lamar and others, business is...well, it remains a business.

title: Worship Is the Cleansing of the Imagination
label: Hydra Head
description: Hydra Head's final (for now) release is a split between Godflesh/Jesu leader Justin K. Broadrick under his new solo moniker, JK Flesh, and prolific electronic noise insurgent Prurient. It serves as a cross-generational cycle between two aggressive sonic explorers.

title: Voodoo
label: Light in the Attic
description: Twelve years since D'Angelo released his dirt-encrusted soul opus in the first month of the new millennium, we have yet to see a follow-up. Heard now on this 2xLP reissue, Voodoo still stands as a paranoid, mysterious, and challenging statement that somehow managed to scale the industry.

title: Real Colors of the Physical World
label: Editions Mego
description: The St. Louis, Mo., experimental composer Joseph Raglani approaches his sound like both a musician and a DJ. His newest offers a hectic mix where synths ripple in overlapping circles, melodies dive into longer tones, beats morph, and static melts.

title: Wild Songs
label: Acéphale
description: Estasy is the project of Emiliano Maggi, an Italian singer/songwriter who has spent the last couple of years releasing low-key CD-Rs and collaborating with visual artists in Rome. The barely captured feel of the songs on his debut album earn it its untamed title.

title: Life Ain't No Joke
label: Def Jam
description: The Chicago teen and Chief Keef associate has been overlooked in part because he spent parts of 2012 in prison right as his city's rap scene started to explode. His second mixtape of the year showcases his ear for pop and his liberal use of Autotune.

title: Bastards
label: One Little Indian
description: Bastards gathers remixes from Björk's ambitious multi-media project Biophilia, including contributions from Death Grips, Hudson Mohawke, Matthew Herbert, and Omar Souleyman.

title: Persistent Malaise
label: Italian Beach Babes
description: On their debut album, the Brighton-based Cold Pumas refine the style of fluid, repitition-based post-punk they showed on early singles but deepen their lyrical focus.

title: LP
label: Spectrum Spools
description: The Nashville, Tenn., producer Ren Schofield's newest Container record shows that techno can be sloppy, unordered, punk, and, above all, casual. The best part about LP, though, is that it isn't precious: It's wily, sharp, and thoughtfully brief.

title: Lucifer in Dub
label: Mexican Summer
description: L.A. neo-psych duo Peaking Lights are about as close as you can get to a modern dub act without actually being one. Their 2012 album Lucifer turned that influence into other strains of cosmic head-trip music, but this follow-up companion piece makes the implicit explicit.

title: Vicious Lies and Dangerous Rumors
label: Island Def Jam
description: Big Boi is known for his voracious, omnivorous listening habits and willingness to abandon his most successful musical formulas; on his second proper solo album, he teams up with artists like Phantogram, Wavves, and Little Dragon, and the result is a puzzling mess.

title: Ten
label: Fascination
description: Girls Aloud are as huge a pop act as the UK has seen in the past decade, yet they've never so much as dented the American charts. This retrospective compilation, which tacks on four new songs, marks their first decade as a band.

title: The Mystery of Heaven
label: Sacred Bones
description: Jim Jarmusch and Jozef Van Wissem's third collaboration this year bears their shared, strong sense of magic and mystery. It's a story told through Jarmusch's feedback-addled guitar parts and the Dutch lutist's forlorn playing.
